text:
Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online announcements of where you are. The website's message was clear: when you tell everyone, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are also letting all kinds of people know where you are, and not all of them are people you want to meet. This made people realize that sharing everything online might not always be good. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a global audience, offering exciting possibilities like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the internet, sharing personal stories and photos. But soon, we find out that the internet can be dangerous and confusing.
However, there is hope. Years ago, a group of online pioneers showed us the way. In the early days of the internet, they explored these dangers. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the challenges of being famous, all before social media existed. These pioneers, the first bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. We should learn from their stories. If we don't learn from history, we might repeat the same mistakes.
In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was created at Cern, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were interested in his bold use of this new medium. Hall shared everything, and nothing was off-limits. His work was very open, but it was also artistic.
One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video called Dark Night. He had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped the blog, but the problem of sharing too much online continues. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you more, you might be disappointed.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, and she lost her job. This is an example of the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online that they wouldn't say in person. But the internet is not a place where we can say anything without consequences. Our online and real lives are connected, and pretending otherwise can lead to big mistakes.
Armstrong's story ended well. She was upset and stopped blogging for a while, but she got married and started blogging again about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned that while the internet lets us say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe that we don't understand. Most scientists agree that we don't know everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt the need to warn the public about the film, calling it "atrocious" and "a very dangerous piece of work." This made the film seem interesting to watch.
At first, the film seemed harmless. Scientists in the film talked about how new discoveries show that the universe is stranger than we thought. But then the film talked about discoveries like the idea that water molecules can be changed by thoughts. I had heard before that a Japanese researcher claimed that the shape of a water molecule could change just by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy and looking bad after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. Some people find this evidence convincing because it is simple and clear. However, many scientists say, "Give me a break." They mean that we need better proof to believe such claims. Nice pictures of crystals are not enough.
The real problem is that the film's claims were not strange enough. For example, some scientists say that water molecules have properties because of a type of energy that comes from nowhere and is linked to a force that is making the universe expand. This evidence comes from many years of research in labs and observatories around the world. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is being pushed by a mysterious force called "dark energy."
Besides the film, other amazing discoveries are being made. Neuroscientists found that our brain's perception of events is about half a second behind reality, but we don't notice because our brain edits it out. Anthropologists think they have found where modern humans first lived and why they left to explore the world. Some theorists even say there are links between life on Earth and the design of the universe.
Science is not finished. In fact, we are further from knowing everything than ever before. Many natural phenomena cannot be understood as well as we once thought. The ideas of chaos and quantum uncertainty show limits to what we can know. Some of the world's top physicists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Despite all these theories, many people think the universe can be described in one word: incredible.

I find writing novels challenging, but writing short stories is fun. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, while writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both are important and make a complete picture that I love. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves, which sometimes turn gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colors attract bees and butterflies, showing the change of seasons.
Since I started writing, I have switched between writing novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. When I finish a group of short stories, I feel like writing a novel. I never write both at the same time because they use different parts of my brain, and I need time to switch from one to the other.
I began my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I started writing short stories. I didn't know much about writing short stories then, so it was difficult, but I found it memorable. Writing short stories helped me expand my fictional world, and readers liked this new side of me. One of my first stories, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad.
One great thing about short stories is that they don't take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story decent, though I might revise it many times. Writing a novel takes a year or two and needs a lot of physical and mental effort. Short stories are a nice change of pace for me. 
Another good thing about short stories is that you can create them from small ideas, like a word or an image. It's like jazz improvisation, where the story leads me. If a story doesn't work out, it's okay. Not every story can be a masterpiece, even for great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver. This is comforting because I can learn from my mistakes and use that in my next story.
When I write novels, I try to learn from my short stories' successes and failures. Short stories are like a testing ground for me as a novelist. It's hard to experiment in a novel, so short stories make writing novels easier for me. My short stories are like soft shadows or faint footprints I leave behind. I remember where I wrote each one and how I felt. They are like guideposts to my heart, and I am happy to share these feelings with my readers.

Science can be very abstract, like philosophy, or very practical, like curing diseases. It has made our lives easier but also brought dangers. Science tries to understand everything from tiny ants to the vast universe, but it doesn't always succeed. It influences poets, politicians, and thinkers. Its beauty is often seen only by experts, and its dangers are often misunderstood. People sometimes think science is more or less important than it really is, and they often ignore its mistakes or exaggerate them. 
Science is full of conflicts. Old ideas are often changed or replaced by new ones, just like in music. New ideas are sometimes laughed at but can become the new standard. Scientists often disagree, and their emotions can run high. This book will talk about how science has changed not just itself but also human thought. We will focus on ideas, not practical things like non-stick frying pans. We will admire these ideas but also question them, knowing that human minds have limits.
Science is always changing. Scientists often prove each other wrong. Usually, these changes don't affect society much, but sometimes they cause big shifts in our beliefs. For example, in the 17th century, science described the universe as a giant clock. Later, physics showed that our observations can change the universe, and we don't fully understand our basic concepts. Some people think this shows science can't explain everything, but usually, scientific changes help us understand and predict nature better. Isaac Newton explained more than Aristotle, and Albert Einstein explained more than Newton. Science makes mistakes but keeps moving forward.
At the end of the 19th century, many physicists thought there was nothing new to discover. Then came radioactivity, X-rays, electrons, quantum mechanics, and more. Biology has also made many discoveries. Some people now say we are close to a complete theory of everything. Maybe. Science is not just a harmless hobby. In the last 200 years, we have started to control nature, sometimes upsetting its balance without understanding the consequences. We need to watch science carefully. Everyone should understand scientific advances because they affect our world and future generations. Science is now part of how we plan and shape our future, and these decisions are important for everyone, not just philosophers. They can affect national budgets, the health of future children, and even life on Earth.

From around 2015, after years of growth, big publishers noticed that ebook sales stopped growing or even went down. This made people question if ebooks would be successful in the long run. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, as his company lost faith in the power of printed books. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still wonder if ebooks will replace print books. This idea keeps our imagination active and causes debates. Why do we think of ebooks and print books as being in a fight, even when evidence shows they can coexist? The answers tell us about our mixed feelings of excitement and fear about new things and changes.
In my research, I found that people often think new technology will replace old ones. Before digital technology, people thought TV would end radio, but radio survived by finding new uses, like in cars. The idea of books disappearing isn't new either. In 1894, people thought phonographs would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times with movies, radio, TV, and smartphones, all thought to end print books. Some feared this would harm culture, while others thought ebooks would bring great benefits. The idea of books disappearing often comes up during technological changes because it shows our hopes and fears about new technology.
We form emotional connections with media like books, TVs, and computers. Studies show we even name our cars or get mad at our laptops. When new technology like e-readers comes, it changes our relationship with things we are used to. This makes us miss what we had before, which is why industries for old products and technologies exist. For example, when the printing press spread in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. When movies got sound in the 1920s, people missed silent films. The same happened with photography and music records. E-readers made people appreciate the feel and smell of old books again.
This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of a disappearing medium will continue to be a popular story about technology's power and our dislike of change. We use familiar stories, like tragedy and endings, to understand change. The story of the book's death shows our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our world and ourselves.

For almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and started writing. I wrote about how some of the greatest minds in the last four hundred years found time each day to do their best work. I looked at how they organized their schedules to be creative and productive. By writing about the simple details of their daily lives—like when they slept, ate, and worked—I wanted to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show that even famous artists have habits like us. 
The French food expert Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, "Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are." I say, "Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward." This book is about the conditions for creative work, not the work itself. It’s about how things are made, not what they mean. But it’s also personal. The writer John Cheever said you can’t even write a business letter without showing something of yourself. Isn’t that true?
In the book, I think about questions I struggle with: How do you do meaningful creative work while also making a living? Is it better to focus completely on one project or to work a little each day? When there isn’t enough time for everything, do you have to give up things like sleep or a clean house? Or can you learn to do more in less time, like my dad always says, "work smarter, not harder"? I don’t have all the answers, but I tried to show how different successful people faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas come from small daily actions and how our work habits affect our work.
The book is called Daily Rituals, but it’s really about people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary, but it can also be a way to use limited resources like time, willpower, and optimism. A good routine helps focus your energy and keeps you from being controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot. By forming good habits, he said, we can focus on more interesting things. Ironically, James himself often procrastinated and couldn’t stick to a schedule.
This book started because I was procrastinating. One Sunday, I was alone at the architecture magazine where I worked, trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was tidying my desk and making coffee. I’m a morning person, good at focusing early but not after lunch. That afternoon, I looked online for information about other writers’ schedules. I found many interesting stories and thought someone should collect them. So, I started the Daily Routines blog and later wrote this book.
The blog was simple; I posted descriptions of people’s routines from biographies, magazine articles, and obituaries. For the book, I expanded and researched more, keeping the short and varied voices that made the blog popular. I let my subjects speak for themselves with quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. This book wouldn’t be possible without the work of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I listed all my sources in the Notes section, which can also guide further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of something that happened when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, decided they couldn't afford a holiday to Spain because interest rates went up. Instead, they went to the English coast. There, on a rainy August day, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. From that moment, he knew he wanted to be a palaeontologist. By the end of university, he knew exactly what kind of palaeontologist he wanted to be. He wasn't interested in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. He wanted to study the very beginnings of life, looking at tiny creatures in ancient rocks.
After finishing his doctoral thesis, Howard worried about finding a job. He knew he was talented, but he also knew that getting a job wasn't always fair. When a job at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied, but he didn't expect much. On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to support another candidate couldn't make it because of an accident. The replacement professor didn't like the other candidate and helped Howard get the job instead. Howard was surprised and grateful, even after he learned the real reason he got the job. He was just happy to have a job doing what he loved.
Howard often thought about how his work was organized and planned, unlike the chaos of everyday life. He realized this when his briefcase, with important lecture notes, was stolen at an Underground station. Angry, he went back to the college, postponed his lecture, and reported the theft. Then, he had coffee with a colleague and a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils there, which would become his biggest challenge and secure his career. If his briefcase hadn't been stolen, he wouldn't have known about this opportunity. He quickly changed his plans, deciding not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students to Scotland. Instead, he focused on finding a way to visit the museum in Nairobi. 
*An ammonite is a type of fossil.

Charles Spence is willing to try almost any food. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. These larvae might look like maggots, but they taste "slightly nutty and floral." Making bug-eating normal is just one of the many food challenges Spence and his team are working on. Spence studies how our senses work together to create the flavors we taste. His research is quietly changing what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurants. Spence and other scientists study how we experience food and drink, a field informally called gastro physics. They look at who we eat with, how food is presented, the color and texture of plates and cutlery, and even background noise, as all these things affect taste. 
Spence's book, "The Perfect Meal," written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, is full of interesting facts for anyone who likes to eat. Did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant usually enjoys their food the most? Or that we eat about 35% more when dining with one other person, and 75% more with three others? Spence's lab in Oxford is simple and not high-tech. "Low-tech, paper and drawing pin stuff," he says. There are soundproof booths that look like big safes, and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can work creatively with chefs who can't afford academic research. Much of his work is funded by a big food company. In the past, research funded by industry was seen as less important in universities. But now, since the government wants universities to show their work has an impact, this type of research is seen as valuable. 
Spence is helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar, often because of government rules. He says it's in their interest to help customers live longer. Many companies make these changes quietly, so regular customers don't notice. "Research shows that if you tell people about the changes, they focus on the taste and don't like it as much," he says. Spence met Heston Blumenthal, a famous experimental chef, while working on a project for a big food producer. People used to think science and food didn't mix, but most food is scientific. Blumenthal and Spence worked together on a dish called "Sound of the Sea" at Blumenthal's restaurant. 
Spence says that in the early 20th century, Italian futurists tried similar ideas, like using frog sounds with frog legs, but it didn't become popular. Now, the food industry uses Spence's sensory science in many products. For example, he found that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, while low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. "It's surprising when shapes affect taste, or when music changes how you taste a flavor," he says. An airline will soon match music with food served to passengers. Last year, a brand released a smartphone app that played music while your ice cream softened, but they didn't match the music to the taste, which Spence says happens often. 
What are dinner parties like at Spence's home? Once, they ate rabbit with the fur wrapped around the cutlery. Another time, they used remote-controlled, multi-colored light bulbs. "We've had dinner parties with a tone generator, headphones, and 10 different drinks to see if they have different pitches." For Spence, home, sweet shops, food conventions, and international gastronomy conferences are all like his lab.

Our brains are busier than ever. We get a lot of information, some true and some not, and we have to decide what is important and what we can ignore. We are also doing more things ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights, and salespeople helped us in shops. Now, we do these things on our own. We try to manage our lives, families, jobs, hobbies, and TV shows, often with the help of our smartphones. These phones help us fit as much as possible into every free moment. 
However, there is a problem. We think we are multitasking, or doing many things at once, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a brain expert at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly from one task to another. This switching has a cost. We are not like expert jugglers; we are more like beginners trying to keep many plates spinning, worried they will fall. Even though we think we are doing a lot, multitasking makes us less efficient. 
Multitasking increases stress hormones, which can make our thinking unclear. It also makes us want more distractions. The part of the brain called the prefrontal cortex is easily distracted by new things. This is a problem because we need this part of the brain to focus. Just having the chance to multitask can hurt our brain performance. Glenn Wilson, a psychology professor, calls this info-mania. His research shows that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. This loss is greater than the loss from being tired.
Russ Poldrack, a brain scientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV at the same time, the information goes to a part of the brain that stores skills, not facts. Without TV, the information goes to the hippocampus, where it is better organized and easier to remember.
Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to answer a text or not. Making decisions is hard for our brains, and small decisions can be as tiring as big ones. After many small decisions, we might make bad choices about important things.
When talking to business leaders and scientists, email is often mentioned as a problem. It is not the email itself, but the large amount of communication. A colleague's 10-year-old son said his father "answers emails" for a living, which is almost true. We feel we must reply to emails, but it seems impossible to do that and get other things done.

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino would break concrete into pieces at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions were not important. Scientists only looked at animal behaviors and their results. They did not think animals had feelings or morals. But now, this is changing. Research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens shows that animals might have emotions. This idea is now being discussed in popular science books like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". This has started a debate: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? In a study with cows, those that opened a gate to get food were happier than those that had help. If cows like solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? People disagree on what these observations mean. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, who wrote "Second Nature", thinks we should stop eating meat. He believes we are close to a big change in ethics, like when slavery ended. Aubrey Manning, a professor, thinks we should rethink how we see animal intelligence. He believes animals have a simpler version of our mind. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop giving animals human traits. These views may never agree because the main issue is philosophical, not just scientific or moral. It is hard to define consciousness, so can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe talks about an experiment with starlings, a type of bird, that he thinks shows they can get depressed. At Newcastle University, starlings were put in two groups. One group had nice cages, and the other had small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid bad worms from another. Later, when only bad worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe thinks the birds in bad cages felt pessimistic. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, believes we will one day see our treatment of animals like we see racism today. He says we cannot support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger. If he were the only one with this view, it might be easy to ignore him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees with him. Manning wrote a textbook on animal behavior. He says we are seeing a change in how we think about animals. In the early 20th century, people thought animals were like humans, then they changed their minds. Now, we are changing again. It is a difficult topic, and people have strong opinions.

Critical thinking is a way to understand what we read or hear better. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., says that people believe arguments help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems and make it harder to think deeply. West says we see a lot of poor thinking and opinions that can confuse us. More data doesn't always mean better knowledge or decisions. 
Reading books has decreased by 10%, and this might affect critical thinking, says Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor. She believes focusing more on visual media like TV and video games can reduce critical thinking because they encourage multitasking instead of focusing on one thing. We don't yet know exactly how technology affects critical thinking. Technology can be both good and bad, and different uses can lead to different results. For example, a computer game might help or hurt critical thinking. Reading online can improve analysis, but too many links can stop deep thinking.
Greenfield says technology changes how we think. Reading helps imagination and critical thinking more than visual media. However, visual media can improve some information processing. But most visual media don't allow time for thinking or imagination. This can lead to people, especially young ones, not reaching their full potential.
How we see technology affects how we think about critical thinking. Video games and thinking skills are a big topic. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, says video games can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and thinking skills in virtual worlds. These games let people explore ideas they might not be able to in real life. As reading and math scores go down, we need to understand how technology affects thinking and analysis.

Matthew Crawford is a writer and a motorcycle mechanic. He used to work in an office but left because he didn't like it. His first book talks about the good things about working with your hands. His latest book is about dealing with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he saw ads on a credit card machine while shopping. He realized that these ads are hard to ignore and take our attention away from what we want to think about. 
Crawford says that because of these distractions, we find it hard to think or remember past conversations. We try to avoid interruptions, so we stop talking to strangers. He believes that things like video games and phone apps are designed to grab our attention and can control us. Many people feel the same way. For example, some office workers complain about emails but still check them in their free time. Studies show that just seeing a phone on a table can distract us. 
Crawford thinks that technology makes it easy for us to focus only on ourselves. This affects how we interact with others. We prefer texting to talking because it's easier. By only interacting with screens, we might lose important social skills. 
He gives an example from his gym. Before, there was one music player for everyone, which sometimes caused disagreements. Now, people use earphones and listen to their own music, making the gym less social. Crawford believes that real connections happen when people work through differences together.
Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we should have rules to reduce noise and distractions in public places. More importantly, he thinks we should do activities that require skill and focus, like cooking or playing sports. These activities help us connect with the real world and other people. They also help us focus better and feel more satisfied.

"‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often define ourselves by our jobs. Usually, we answer this question in a few words. But when you are a philosopher, like me, it is a bit harder to answer. Saying you are a philosopher can sound a bit arrogant. People might think you believe you have special knowledge or wisdom. This is not true; philosophers are just like everyone else. But this idea makes me pause. Why do people think this way about philosophers? One reason is that philosophers are seen as people who think deeply and value intellectual life. The Greek philosopher Aristotle (384 – 322 BCE) said that a life of thinking, or a philosophical life, was the best life. Not many modern philosophers agree, but philosophy is still linked with deep thinking. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said, ‘the unexamined life is not worth living’. He meant that just following what everyone else does is not satisfying. Thinking about our lives helps us make our own choices. But you don’t need to read a lot of philosophy books or spend all your time thinking to live an examined life. It means looking closely at our daily experiences to see if they are important. You don’t have to be a wise person living away from society to do this. In fact, to help people, philosophy should be practical and shared with others. This leads to another reason people misunderstand philosophers: academic philosophy has become very separate from everyday life. This is partly because of how universities work. Philosophers often write for expensive and hard-to-read journals, so they don’t get to share their ideas with many people. For most people, philosophy seems far from real life. If philosophers used to fight this idea, many have stopped trying. Universities have created a place where philosophers are isolated, and many support this. Some areas of philosophy focus on very specific debates, making it hard for even other philosophers to understand, let alone the general public. Philosophy has, in some cases, moved away from society. This needs to change. I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I work in ethics, which is about judging human actions. But I feel this title doesn’t fully explain my work. Ethics is often seen as about rules and laws. Recently, ethics has come to mean applied ethics, which looks at whether certain social practices are fair. Ethicists today try to decide if an action is ‘ethical’ or right. These are important questions, and I often think about them. But philosophy is more than this. A typical discussion might start with whether downloading films illegally is wrong (it is) and then look at how we think about responsibility, art, and consumerism. Philosophy helps us look more closely at our actions and beliefs. Sometimes we find out things we already know; other times, we see that our beliefs are hard to defend. By examining these ideas, we help everyone."

People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and gourmands, might think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, in history, philosophers have often talked about food to explain other ideas, like learning. Sometimes, discussions that seem to be about food are actually about other, bigger ideas. 
For example, the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus talked about enjoying life and avoiding pain in many areas, not just food. But today, his name is often linked to a love of eating and drinking. We see his name used in restaurants and food websites because businesses think it will help them sell more if people believe famous philosophers approve of their products.
Food is a big part of our social and cultural life. It doesn't just appear; it comes from history and is shared with people around us. Our communities give us people to eat with and help grow and share food. We deal with food more often than any other thing, making it an interesting topic for philosophy.
Once food is ready, critics talk and write about it. But why do they have such an important role? One philosopher says that tasting food is not a special skill; food critics are just better at describing tastes. Philosophers have not studied taste as much as they have studied sight, and this should change.
Another part of food is its beauty. We say paintings or music are beautiful, but not usually food. Some philosophers think that with modern cooking, food should be part of discussions about beauty, like art or poetry. But food is eaten and gone, unlike art, which lasts over time. So, some think food cannot be considered in the same way as art.
There are also many ethical questions about food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our choices show our beliefs, and philosophers ask why we make these choices.
Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a special duty to their guests because of love and friendship. At home, everyone shares food and time together. Professional cooks have responsibilities to their employers and the food, so their kitchens are not open to everyone, only to trained people.
A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ looks at how food can help connect different cultures. This happens in two ways: by enjoying each other's food and by eating together, which has been important in international diplomacy for a long time. The essay includes many interesting stories that make this part of food philosophy exciting for everyone.

Rob Daviau, from the US, creates 'legacy' board games. He thought the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. He wondered if board games could have a story or if choices made in one game could affect the next game. He changed a classic board game called Risk to make a new version called Risk Legacy. In this game, choices made by players have lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, write on the board, or open packets with new rules. The game is played over several sessions, and past actions become part of the game. Daviau said, "You could point to the board and say: 'Right here! You did this!'"
Daviau then worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players try to stop diseases. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was very popular, SeaFall was a big test for the legacy format because it was not based on an earlier game. Set in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century), players explore and conquer new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all possible player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how the game will play out. Jaime Barriga, a tester for SeaFall, said, "It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the first few games are great, but then it starts to have problems, and you have to fix everything."
Legacy board games were not expected to become popular. Daviau thought it would only interest a few people. He said, "I thought it was different and good, but strange and unexpected. I thought only a few people would like it." However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He thinks it's a big step forward in game design. "It's a new level of excitement," he said. "There's nothing more exciting for a board gamer than learning a new game or way to play."
Another fan, Ben Hogg, liked the adventure of legacy games. "At first, I was worried about changing and damaging the board," he said. "But Pandemic Legacy changed that. Most people don't watch the same movie twice. You're buying an experience. It's like the stories in video games." The legacy format is similar to video games and popular TV series. Daviau wanted to be a TV writer but ended up in game design. He still loves telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compares making a legacy game to writing a book. "You need to know how it starts and ends," he said. "But you also need more than just an outline."
Daviau feels proud of his idea but is curious to see what others do with it. He thinks gamers will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, from the publisher of SeaFall, believes the legacy format is a big change. "It changes how you think about what a board game can be," he said.

One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and squeezed into a small drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online and seemed like something from a children’s movie. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think animals are like humans. This is especially true for octopuses, which are very smart even though they look very different from us. Octopuses can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and even play in complex ways.
Some people think it is unscientific to say animals are like humans, but Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, disagrees. He says that ignoring the human-like traits of animals, which he calls "anthropodenial," is more common. Research shows that animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, being self-aware, and understanding others' motives. Animals are smarter than we often think.
In the past, people believed animals were smart. In medieval Europe, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. In the 19th century, scientists like Charles Darwin believed that the difference between human and animal minds was not very big. But in the 20th century, people started to see animals as simple machines that only responded to rewards and punishments. This view became popular when humans began destroying animal habitats and ignoring animal welfare.
Dr. de Waal believes we are now starting to understand animal intelligence better. He says that the best tests of animal intelligence consider the unique skills of each species. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hide their nuts. In her book, "The Soul of an Octopus," naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might think we are not very smart because we cannot change the color of our skin.
Dr. de Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean, but he knows that stories like Inky’s help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the monkeys with cucumbers got upset because grapes are better. The study was published in a scientific journal, but a short video of the experiment convinced more people of the findings. This shows how our minds work in interesting ways.

Robots used to be something we only read about in science fiction books. Now, they are becoming a big part of our world, changing how we work just like machines did during the industrial revolution. For many years, robots have been used in car factories and other manufacturing areas. But now, experts say robots will soon be used in many more areas, and many countries are not ready for this big change.
Most people agree that robots will change the way we work. About two-thirds of people think robots will do most of the jobs humans do now in the next 50 years. However, 80% of people also believe their own jobs will still be around in the same way. This is not true. Every job sector will be affected by robots in the coming years. For example, an Australian company, Fastbrick Robotics, has a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour. This is a job that would take two human workers almost a whole day to do. In San Francisco, a company called Simbe Robotics has a robot named Tally that moves around supermarkets to check if products are in the right place and priced correctly.
People who support robots say that robots cannot fix or program themselves yet. This means there will be new jobs for people who can work with robots. But some people worry that we are not ready for the changes robots will bring, especially the loss of human interaction at work.
Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots are changing jobs. He says that in two years, many robots will be smarter and able to work with humans. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will have laws about robots. In five years, salaries in the robotics field will go up by 60%, but many jobs will still be empty because there are not enough skilled workers.
Dr. Zhang believes that people with lower skills will be affected by robots. He says they should not wait for the government to protect their jobs but should learn new skills. People cannot expect to do the same job forever anymore.
New technologies will create new types of robots for consumers, like robots that live with us at home and interact with us in smart ways. This is a big chance for companies, but it also means we need new rules to keep us safe. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future. Countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) to stay competitive.

George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it's there." The reporter's question showed that many people are curious about why someone would do something so dangerous and seemingly pointless. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams and face the unknown. It also suggests that climbing might be about adventure and fun.
In 1967, a Bolivian writer named Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called "Games that Climbers Play." He described seven different types of climbing activities, each with its own rules. He said that the way you climb, like using more or less equipment, should follow the rules of the specific climbing activity. Over the years, this idea has become very popular in the climbing community, influencing everything from climbing magazines to discussions around campfires.
Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. However, climbing can also be very limiting, like when you are stuck in a tent during a storm. This shows a contradiction in climbing: it can feel both freeing and restricting. But some people think that having fewer choices while climbing can make life simpler, which is a kind of freedom.
Joe Fitschen, a US rock climber, suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is part of our nature as humans. We like to take on challenges and test our limits, even if it's risky. This means the joy of climbing might be more about our biology than logical thinking.
Another idea comes from US academic Brian Treanor, who says climbing can help develop important qualities like courage, humility, and respect for nature. He thinks these qualities are important in today's world, which often avoids risk. Climbing can help people grow and live well even outside of climbing.
Some climbers believe that those who climb without help from others or technology must be very dedicated to succeed. Experts Ebert and Robinson argued that climbing is more impressive when done alone or without extra help, like bottled oxygen. This idea caused some debate because it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.
Finally, climbing can also be understood by looking beyond Western ideas. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "in the zone" while climbing. The physical effort, the focus, and the problem-solving involved are similar to techniques in Zen philosophy, which aims for a state of perfect peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became very important in classical music. He was a serious and thoughtful person who focused on European piano music. He wrote and played a lot but did not teach much. People who knew him well saw he could be fun, but he was serious during concerts. His life was full of study, travel, and performances. 
Then, a few years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take him seriously because he had not taught many students before. He thought of a saying: ‘You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play and was impressed. Kit played very well from memory and gave Brendel a CD of a recital where he played beautifully. Brendel thought, “I have to make time for him.” Kit’s performance was very rare and special.
As Brendel is retiring, Kit is starting his career, but Brendel is careful to make sure Kit does not get too tired too quickly. Kit, now 19, is always busy learning new things like languages, math, computer coding, and playing tennis, with his mother always watching over him. He also writes music. Brendel says this is important because writing music helps you understand it better. Kit has an amazing memory and can read music very well. He listens carefully to his own playing and to Brendel’s advice. When Brendel explains something, Kit understands and can do it. 
Brendel is careful not to raise too many expectations. He gets upset when newspapers call Kit the future great pianist of the 21st century because it puts too much pressure on him. Kit can play some things very well, but he still needs more time and experience for others. Critics expecting perfection could be harmful.
Now at 80 years old, Brendel is more relaxed. He says, ‘When I was young, I didn’t want to be famous quickly, but I wanted to achieve certain things by 50. When I reached 50, I had done most of them, but I continued. Even though I don’t have the physical strength now, I still think about many pieces I never played. I don’t perform anymore, but it’s a nice new chapter in my life.’

When I was a child, I always thought gardens were beautiful places. My Grandad’s garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went gently down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds singing in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – places to escape, find peace, and be alone. Grandad’s garden was simple. He didn’t have a greenhouse like some of his neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic covering broken glass.
At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn’t without humor, though. He liked to say things like, ‘It’s immaterial to me,’ instead of just saying, ‘I don’t mind.’ He probably wished he had done more with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber. Plumbing wasn’t his passion; it was just his job. He wasn’t very ambitious, but he and my mom once thought about moving to Canada, though it didn’t happen. He was very good at fixing things around the house, like making bookshelves or cupboards.
My parents only moved house once, but my mother liked to change the furniture often. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I did like the two brass candlesticks on it, but my mom thought they were too fancy and took them away. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister got lessons instead. When I asked my mom later why I didn’t get lessons, she said, ‘You’d never have practiced.’
I loved going to the river. I would go there with a fishing net and old sandals. I’d find a spot to take off my sandals and look for fish to catch with my net. After trying to keep them alive at home, I would put them back in the river. I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it didn’t seem possible until my dad said, ‘There’s a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.’ My dad usually didn’t like gardening, but he saw how much I loved it. I think he hoped it would be a good choice for me.

Lawrence MacEwen is on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck, and so am I. A strong wind from the Atlantic is blowing hard, but Lawrence is not bothered. He is at home here. His sheepdog, Tie, comes over, and Lawrence gently pets him. Lawrence is showing me around his island. He points north and shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.’ I see heavy clouds raining on Rum’s big mountains. ‘Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay,’ he adds. Suddenly, Lawrence says he needs to move his sheep because rain is coming our way. As we walk down the hill, he tells me about the island: Muck is three kilometers long and half as wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. We stop talking to herd the sheep. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to gather the sheep but is not doing well. Lawrence tells him to go right, but Tie goes straight into the flock, causing confusion. Lawrence sounds disappointed and says, ‘That will never do.’ The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence manages the farm with his wife, Jenny. Their son, Colin, takes care of the island cottages, and their daughter, Mary, runs the island hotel with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. ‘They leave the house and come back only when they’re hungry,’ Mary says. But living on the island has its challenges. For example, electricity is only available sometimes. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to come on. The next morning, Mary prepares breakfast using a flashlight. I get used to it, along with having no mobile phone service. Mary tells me, ‘There is mobile reception on the hill. Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone in the drawer.’ So I do the same. Life on Muck feels wonderfully unusual. Today, the boat brings groceries and three musicians with instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with everyone tapping their feet to the music. That night, sitting by a warm fire while it rains outside, Lawrence tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. ‘Her father bought a small farm on the Isle of Soay from a newspaper ad without seeing it. He had never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.’ Did Jenny know how to run a farm? ‘She was good at typing,’ Lawrence says. I go to bed with the sound of rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food coming from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I bring it back to Mary, and by 7 pm, the fish is on the table, tasting amazing. I also think about my ferry ride the next morning to another island. Many ferries had been canceled in the past two months because of rough seas. If my ferry didn’t come, I would have to stay on Muck for two more days. Secretly, I hoped for that.

The game design industry used to be mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is taken seriously. This doesn't surprise experts. Making video games is not easy. When a new movie comes out, video games based on it need many team members and months of hard work. Like many industries, it's hard to get into, but it is growing.
Jim Donelly, who works for an online games magazine, says it's hard to make progress in big companies or to have a say in big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. They need not only directors who manage the whole game but also people who design parts of the game.
How can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim thinks differently. He says the only way is to make games. The tools are available. You won't get a job if you haven't created something. Game design is more a way of life than just a job. Like any creative work, you have to do it to make it real.
Another expert, John Field, sees other options. He agrees that making games is important, but it's more complicated. Many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry's needs. Even fewer have the creative talent, technical skills, vision, and business ability to really make a difference.
Can you do it alone? John says it's possible but difficult. A good postgraduate course in games can help and provide support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all kinds of entertainment and arts. They might have worked for a few years after graduation but realized games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and know how diverse games are becoming. Connections are important too. Networking can help you get ahead in games, just like in other fields.
The old idea of a teenage boy playing games all day is outdated. Now, games are seen as a grown-up activity. Families play together on interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. Games are popular with large audiences and are a great way to learn. He sees many possibilities and opportunities in this area.

Since I was a child, all I wanted to do was play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I'm thankful for that. I had a friend who came to the park with us, and his dad was very pushy. He always said, "You can't do this, you can't do that." My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play and never played football again. I'm glad that didn't happen to me, but I know it could have been different. 
When I score an amazing goal from far away, people often say it's just luck, but it's not. I've practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. Only by practicing can you score the great goals that feel so exciting. The best players in the world have amazing talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes you see young players bumping into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I try to show them how to enjoy learning skills. 
I used to play every sport at school. I joined in everything, from rounders and baseball to athletics and basketball. Now I know it's important to get a good education, but back then, football was all I thought about. The teachers were doing a good job, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books even though he's too young to sit still for long. I hope that when he kicks the books around, it doesn't mean he will be like me in that way.
At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so some of us younger players could play for the first team, but he didn't make a big deal about it. He never said, "This is your big chance," but we knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost, and a TV presenter said, "You can't win anything with kids." That made us realize how much we had to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team.
I rely a lot on close friends and family. But having a lot of money can sometimes cause problems. For example, people say, "I can't believe you let your mother keep working." Of course, I've helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would be upset if they thought they should be on my payroll. My mum doesn't earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. On the other hand, I like using my money to make life easier for the people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think, and it doesn't solve everything. After I stop playing, I think I'll take a year off or maybe longer to do things I haven't been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing. I can't do that now because if I broke a leg skiing and couldn't play football again, I wouldn't be insured.

Sam Carter was the reason we were living at Reef Point. Sam was my dad's agent in Los Angeles. He was desperate to find us a cheap place to live because my dad couldn't write anything sellable in Los Angeles. This was bad for Sam because he could lose important clients and money. During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point was not popular with day-trippers. The road was not nice, and the nearby resort, La Carmella, was more attractive for those with some money. Only people who were broke or loved surfing would come to Reef Point. But when the weather got hot, many people came, and the place became lively. After months of being almost alone, we were now surrounded by people and activities. My dad was busy trying to write a script on time and was in a bad mood. He didn't notice that I spent most days on the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn't have a dog, but Rusty decided to stay with us. I tried to chase him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him water. My dad half-heartedly threw a boot at him, but Rusty didn't care and stayed closer. I asked my dad, "Who do you think he belongs to? He seems to think he belongs to us." My dad replied, "You're wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him." Rusty loved the beach and often dug things up to bring to me. Sometimes he brought things he didn't dig up, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, which I had to return to their owners. Rusty also liked to swim and always came with me, even though I could swim faster and farther. He never got discouraged. That day, we had been swimming. My dad, having finished his script, went to Los Angeles to deliver it. Rusty and I spent the afternoon together in and out of the sea. As the sun set and it got cooler, we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and seemed tireless. They would choose a wave, stand on their boards, and ride it to the shore. One surfer stood out to me. She was very skilled and made the others look clumsy. She decided to finish for the day and rode a final wave to the shore. "Hi," she said, "why didn’t you join us?" "I haven’t got a surfboard," I replied. "You could get one." "No money." "You’re British, aren’t you? Are you visiting?" "No, I live here." "Is your father American?" "No. He came here to write the film script of a novel he wrote." "No kidding? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?" "Rufus Marsh." "You mean, Tall as the Morning?" I nodded. "I read that cover to cover." She looked at me with new interest, and I thought this was how it always was. People were friendly but not really interested until I mentioned Tall as the Morning.

Violet Hetherington was standing in a long line at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the ship Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had told her to arrive late to avoid waiting, but this advice turned out to be wrong. An announcement said there was a problem with the computer system, which made the passengers upset. They had paid a lot for this trip and expected better service. Violet felt like leaving, especially when she realized she had lost her phone. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left it there because all her contacts were saved on the phone. Her son Harry always warned her about this kind of mistake. 
Violet asked a friendly couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message, asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was at her home. If it wasn't there, she would have trouble finding the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her felt relieved, but she didn't tell Harry that. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother, while her younger son Daniel was more understanding because he was forgetful too. 
Finally, the line started moving, and Violet gave her travel documents to board the ship. She felt disappointed when she saw the ship's foyer, which looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were fake wood panels, lots of chandeliers, shiny brass, and carpets like those in airports. She followed signs to the elevators, which were full of tired passengers. Violet was squeezed against the side as the elevator stopped at each floor. At last, she reached the twelfth floor and was happy to find her room had the balcony she wanted. She had paid extra to make sure she could see the sea, ignoring Annie's advice to wait for a last-minute deal.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he didn't know he was about to discover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures for a book about the history of Portage Park in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a talent for taking interesting photos. Since then, Maloof has collected many of Maier’s belongings, including her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. 
One morning, Maloof looked at all these items and realized he had found something special by chance. ‘When I bought all this, I didn’t know what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily sold it all to someone else.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They talked to families who hired her as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed her film. 
Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be private and a bit unusual, always carrying a camera. She wore large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. ‘On her day off, she would leave with her camera in the morning and return late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier to care for his daughter. ‘She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ 
Maier knew a lot about theatre and movies. Although she wasn’t very social, she wasn’t afraid to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, sometimes recording them on audiotape. She seemed very focused on her ‘second job’ of capturing the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anyone stop her.’ Maier’s work was pure art; she didn’t do it for money. Her photos often showed women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. 
Photography expert Larry Silverman finds Maier’s pictures very interesting. He sees the influence of other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her style on her own. ‘Was Vivian very skilled, or did she take ideas from others?’ Maloof often wonders if he will ever look through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. 
Interestingly, Maloof wasn’t interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her photos, he started taking his own pictures. ‘As I learned more about photography and looked at her work again, I realized it was about the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized it was more important than I ever imagined. Now, our goal is to make sure people know Vivian Maier’s name and get her into the history books.’

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular, and she was calm even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her novel to the officer, who asked, ‘What’s it about?’ This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are a series of crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complicated. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found that the past gave her more chances for her characters to face problems. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I asked how it feels to be successful at a young age, she said it’s nice to come from a small country because everyone feels proud of her success. She added that it’s annoying when people think her book is not serious. She wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, with each part half the length of the one before. The book gets faster as it goes. I asked if it matters if readers notice this. She said she wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if readers cared, they could find them. Even with its unusual structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery with a gripping story. Surprisingly, she didn’t plan the book in advance. She would write herself into a difficult situation and then find a way out. She also wanted the book to be fun for readers. We talked about her love for TV drama series. I asked if she might want to write for TV. She said, ‘That could be pretty cool.’ She was very enthusiastic and laughed often. She loves talking about her work and New Zealand. She notices how her imagination changes when she is in different places. She understands why writers leave New Zealand for busy places to be around more people. But for now, New Zealand will stay her home. I hope it gives her ideas for more books.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved making things in his dad’s garage and playing the guitar. These two hobbies became his job for the last forty years: he builds steel-string, acoustic guitars by hand. Jonny says, ‘I’m still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood make such a beautiful sound? And using different types of wood makes different sounds. It still surprises me.’
Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a holiday job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I thought if you wanted something, you made it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and woods changed the sound, and how to put them together.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny built from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making other things for a long time. ‘We drew model boats and airplanes and then built them, so I knew the process. My father taught us how to use tools like saws and chisels. I also fixed and customized instruments for my friends.’
Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a job. ‘I also liked painting and sculpture,’ he says. After school, he decided to study architecture at university. ‘Architecture involves design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea,’ he remembers. But halfway through, he left the course. ‘I was too independent for it,’ he says. ‘But I realized I wanted to build guitars. It’s like sculpture because you shape sound. And it seemed more practical than pure art because you make things people use.’
Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. At first, he sold guitars for just the cost of the materials, but as he became known as a great guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just getting by.’ He can only make ten guitars a year, which limits his income. In the early years, he worked hard to become known. He went to music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his guitars, which was hard for him.
Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought the best acoustic guitars were made in the USA,’ he says. ‘UK-made guitars weren’t seen as good, even though we have always had good courses and skills here. But now, our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.’ Jonny says you can learn valuable techniques in classes, and he thinks new instrument-makers should take courses. However, he also believes there is no substitute for trial and error. ‘Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If someone else teaches you, you learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’

When talking about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a tradition, and many writers mention Dr. Johnson's famous comment from the 18th century: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This is still true today. However, many people try to explain why English people talk so much about the weather and often fail. They think English people talk about the weather because they are interested in it. For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says the English weather is not exciting, so he doesn't understand why people talk about it so much. He notes that England doesn't have extreme weather like tornadoes or blizzards. On the other hand, English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that the weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that living near the ocean and a continent means you never know what weather you will get.
My research shows that both Bryson and Paxman miss the point. English people don't talk about the weather because they care about it. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to start conversations and connect with each other. Phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not really about the weather. They are greetings or ways to start a conversation. This is similar to how monkeys groom each other to bond socially.
There are specific times when English people use weather talk. It can be a greeting, a way to start a conversation, or a topic to fill awkward silences. This means English people do talk about the weather a lot, which makes others think they are obsessed with it. An English conversation might start with weather talk, use it to break the ice, and return to it when there is nothing else to say. This is why people think English people are very interested in the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were already interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. But they really wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. When she couldn't find a historical novel to help explain life at the Wall in Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started a new career as a writer in 2001. She felt it was a big change. ‘Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but not as tiring. My old teaching friends are jealous because I still connect with children through my stories.’ Alice wants her books to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. ‘Many books for teenagers now are about negative experiences. They are well written,’ she adds, ‘but many are dark or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.’ Alice always taught English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy. She loves seeing children go from being bored to interested and from not understanding to understanding. She sees her writing as a way to keep teaching. She was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also suggested she try a creative writing course. Alice was surprised. ‘I’d been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me. But I didn’t want to spend my summer holiday doing a course I didn’t think I needed.’ Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction. She only found out a few days before she had to leave. ‘I sat at the computer and made up a story about a Roman couple and their baby.’ Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted. During the course, other students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and he helped her edit the novel. Alice says, ‘My mother-in-law thinks we’re rival authors, but I think we work well together. He reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests changing the words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.’

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. This race would be between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 
‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before. It’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. Unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, Alistair wore full winter cycling clothes. He wasn’t worried about the cold. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he’ll even make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’
The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and ended at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, which is 350 meters up. This was not a problem for the car, but Alistair had a tough start with a steep hill. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny got in the car and drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?
Jonny’s confidence was tested right away. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first problem. A big tractor came out of a field and blocked the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor moved, Jonny was back on the road, driving into the morning mist.
Alistair was having a hard time with the hill. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he walked with the bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, the ground was open, and with the sun shining, he could go fast. He put his head down, feet on the pedals, and picked up speed.
In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The villages in this part of Yorkshire are very old, and the roads are not made for fast driving. Jonny had to drive slowly around a narrow corner and through a stream on the road. After the last village, the road was straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, coming to the finish from the other side. He reached the line and stopped. 
Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, ‘Is he here?’ When they said no, he raised his arms and said, ‘Yes!’ A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said, feeling disappointed. ‘I’m gutted.’

Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience. The first thing you notice is the silence. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hear the echo of your shot. The well-kept grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds make you feel like you are in a different world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to think only about the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence is broken by applause and cheers. I hear them, but they seem far away. I don’t really notice the fifteen thousand people watching me or the millions around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life.
I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach forever, taught me that this is the most important tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends that I would play there and win one day. Before 2008, I played and lost twice, both times against Federer. In 2006, I was just happy to be there, even though Federer beat me easily. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mind, not my skills, that let me down. I cried a lot after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it’s worse when you know you had a chance. My uncle Toni, who is a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me, even when I win.
