But after that loss, he told me not to cry and that there would be more chances. I didn’t believe him and thought it was my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete’s career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I felt I missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right. I got another chance in 2008, just one year later. I was sure I had learned from my defeat and that my mind was ready this time. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends, but we didn’t talk about the match. They knew I was already thinking about it in my mind, and I needed to keep that space for myself until the match started.

In April 1957, a young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. She wrote home saying, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made her famous with articles and TV shows about her research on chimpanzees. She also wrote popular books, including the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages.
Jane Goodall is one of the most famous female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventures and dreams but miss the importance of her work. Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading scientist in her field. She helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.
Before her research, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know that they have emotions and social systems similar to humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves.
Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. When she was five, she disappeared one day, and her family and police searched for her. She was found with straw in her hair and clothes. Jane explained she wanted to know how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours to watch. This curiosity was an early sign of her interest in biology.

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist who can speak in many different voices. During our first conversation, she used the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children's TV, cartoons, and even some work training videos. Recently, she did a voiceover about back injuries and had to quickly learn how to say many medical words.
Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. Many actors think they can do funny voices, and some can, but there is more to it. You have to make the script come alive for people who can't see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceover work, but they often don't get the parts because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.
After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning to become a regular actor. During the course, she sang jingles for TV ads. One day, someone at the recording studio asked her to try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. She thought it was silly but tried it for fun and got a big part. Shirley realized she was good at voices and decided to focus on voiceover work. In her second film, she played the main character and also her brother and mother.
Adult female actors often do voices for small boys and girls because their voices are lighter. Hiring child actors is complicated and takes a lot of time, which production companies want to avoid. Shirley has learned to make different sounds and collects new voices by watching children's TV. She enjoys working on cartoons the most, but she also does educational videos and adverts for things like vacuum cleaners. These can be hard because she has to sound excited about things she doesn't care about. She says smiling while talking makes her voice sound happy.
The competition for voiceover work is tough, and having a good showreel, which is a recording of what you can do, is very important. Shirley says it's worth investing in a strong showreel and there are agencies that help with this. She believes she succeeded through hard work and not just talent. Making a showreel, visiting film and TV companies, and practicing voices are all about setting goals and not giving up.
For those interested in voiceover work, Shirley suggests attending workshops that teach different types of voiceover. She loves voices and often becomes the characters she plays. Sometimes, after doing a certain voice in the studio, she keeps speaking that way for hours or even days. Her children are used to hearing her talk in different voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because being a cartoonist is a job many kids dream about, like being a race car driver. But most people give up these dreams and choose more realistic jobs, like becoming a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make money by drawing doodles, like the ones in school notebooks, seems silly. But some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. 
For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my drawings to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on.
To become a cartoonist, you don’t need a university degree, much money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are not high, but it’s still a hard job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you feel you can't do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.
The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, a caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t refuse any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything.
What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs at newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create the work and sell it. The better you are at selling, the better you will do. I’ve seen cartoonists with average talent but great business skills do better than artistic geniuses who lack business sense.
It surprises me how many people have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t let others see their work! To protect your work legally, just draw a little ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it’s more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it’s not a disaster – it can actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and getting rid of things I didn't need. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to get rid of this guitar? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it away when a young man came up to me, looking confused. He asked, "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, but I already felt a bit sorry. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. 
In the years after, I often felt sad about what I had done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. I felt the same way when I read the email from a man named Keith Rushton, who fixes and sells guitars. He told me, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold many times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell it back to me for a fair price. I almost cried with happiness. I had forgotten that my dad used to put name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange story!
My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was very popular then. I loved its calming and gentle sound, and it was easy for beginners. But I didn’t make much progress, so I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t have to play well to be a rock star. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I stood up and put a strap over my shoulder because the electric guitar is usually played standing up. My fingers remembered how to play, even though I couldn’t draw the chords. My fingertips felt the pain of pressing the strings to play a chord. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone, so now I think I need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are other people my age with a similar story. We could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!

There has been a lot of talk about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them. We often lose dreams when we wake up early. The last hour or two of sleep, which we often miss, is mostly REM sleep, where we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM sleep, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night. This shows that dreams are important. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with Sigmund Freud, who said that understanding dreams helps us understand our minds. But it wasn't that simple. Later research showed that dreams have physical origins, not just psychological ones. Now, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study. It found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that people who are interested in creativity use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don't teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Stickgold says dreams help us connect things in new and surprising ways. They help us find new patterns and ideas. For example, when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They think in unexpected ways, which is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a dream I can barely remember seems to help me think better. On those days, words and ideas come to me quickly. I don't know how it works, but it does. Creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We all live in a complex world and need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, you can see the sea and some empty frames on the walls, along with photos of her two daughters. Susie is a well-known copyist artist, which means she can paint copies of famous artworks. She can make a painting look like a 20th-century impressionist piece or a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait. However, she doesn't keep her own work because they are sold as soon as she finishes them.
Susie has been a copyist artist for 30 years and has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that even art experts sometimes think they are the originals. While the original paintings are worth millions, Susie's copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how long she spends on them. She has many clients, including galleries and private collectors, but she doesn't usually say who they are. Some collectors like to show off her copies as if they were the real thing. 
Susie is honest about her work. She tries to make her copies look as real as possible and signs her name on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as an original, and Susie has never done that. She knows people who have gotten into trouble for making fakes. Although she has had financial struggles, her situation is better now, and she doesn't want to risk her reputation.
Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after finishing her art degree. She didn't earn much, but it helped her learn to be precise, which is important in her current work. She advises young artists to learn to draw accurately and study a lot. Susie can copy many styles, but she now focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 
Some people think modern art is easy, but Susie says it's not. Impressionists painted quickly but were also very careful, which is hard to do well. Although Susie is very skilled, she doesn't create her own original art. She has tried, like painting fishing nets, but they looked too much like photos. Susie is a perfectionist and is happy with her work as a copyist.

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur loved the sea more than anything, except maybe being the fastest on it. She was obsessed with sailing since she was a child. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, normal life seemed unimportant, and people always wanted to know about the race. She quickly wanted to return to the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and workplace for 94 days. She explained how she planned everything carefully, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. Preparation was very important to her. She proudly showed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and bags of medical items. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.
Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, an island in the south Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. She saw abandoned whaling stations and felt it was a warning about how we take what we want and move on. When I visited Ellen’s office, she explained why we need to act now to save the planet. She said, "No one is making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious and limited. We need to find ways to not use them up." At first, her message was to use less, but then she realized we should focus on re-using. She talks passionately about things like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, and talked to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Sailing seemed selfish compared to this. This is about finding how my voice can help. It really matters."
Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and schools to help young people think about a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It is a big part of who I am. At sea, you are connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. My new message is not as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become a very famous teenager. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to encourage kids to try outdoor activities. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.
Some experienced Everest climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They believe a young climber might be physically strong but might not be emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these opinions before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – we have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.'
I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father wants him to? Paul says, 'This is not about me wanting to be famous because of my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later, but we decided, why not now? We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on reaching my goal.'
In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a chance to set a record. The more exciting the record, the more people are interested. This is a challenge for Jordan. People might say that focusing on records takes away the fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to share his story with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I am studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't have their music. The numbers are not good for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and classical albums sell only about 300 copies each. I find this hard to believe. Why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract many people, especially teenagers, who buy most music and concert tickets. Some teenagers do go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big fan of classical music. I like many types of music, but I listen to classical music only about 3% of the time. 
Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Experts say we can't focus for more than about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop songs also have lyrics that interest us more than long classical pieces without words. Classical music is powerful but doesn't talk about things teenagers care about. 
The way we listen to music has changed. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why people like classical concerts more as they get older, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They like classical music when they play it, but it's not their first choice when they relax. They prefer pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too, but she didn’t hear Bonnie. Bonnie didn’t mind if her mother heard because she knew how Bonnie felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school with many different buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside. It was confusing at first. Then she saw signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," said Bonnie, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be kicked out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not start now?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie liked horses and treated them well. The horses were well cared for, she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she walked along, looking at each one. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony as she touched its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best one here!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," said Bonnie, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, which made Bonnie happy. She enjoyed putting a saddle on Maverick’s back and forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed when she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I’m serious because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She felt Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by how quietly confident he is. Cody is a 15-year-old from Australia who has already released many successful songs. How did a relaxed surfer end up performing on stage for thousands of fans? Cody explains, ‘I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven.’ He remembers how it all started. ‘But I was swimming every day and surfing. Those were the things that mattered most to me back then. I had my life planned and lots to do. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online.’ These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of him and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, saying they wanted more videos. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were amazing. Cody was also a very good swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches and focused on improving his sport. But then record companies contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a music deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. ‘It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13 years old, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?’ He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. ‘It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,’ he says, remembering their shocked faces. ‘I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world.’ So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody says it’s important to have great people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, we all have days of doubt. ‘Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, “How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?” My little brother is eight years old, and he’s travelling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life,’ Cody admits. ‘I worry about that sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support and encourage me in everything I do.’ Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big chance, even when it’s a bit scary. ‘It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,’ Cody says. ‘Now, to be going to countries I never thought I’d visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever.’

I jumped out of bed, lifted the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. There was a new crack in the ice shining in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked towards the sandbags that were there to stop the buildings from flooding when the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags. Last week, I worked with many people from the town for long hours to show I could do it. But my grandfather didn’t seem to notice. 
With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile of dark water made by the factory in Milltown. There was ice on both sides, and then solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It’s better than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.
‘Morning, Rex,’ Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. ‘Watch where you’re going!’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ My wetsuit should have made that clear. He sees me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘Why train? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. His words hurt, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom came over with a kind smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’s always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero. He showed me photos of him in National Geographic. Those old photos are still on his wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies now, and maybe one day, my own photo in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay close to him, even though he’s grumpy. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my trip.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse in the backyard.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unfinished painting by Grandpa. It was different from his other works. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river, but not one she knew. It might not even be a real river, just an imaginary one. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green. The eye was drawn to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Yet, Jess was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, hiding her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? I mean, for him to be so specific. Maybe he will add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" "Someone who gives an artist ideas." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint. He would say the muse wasn't being kind to him or that he needed to be nice to the muse for a difficult part. He never suggested the muse was her. She thought he meant a goddess, not a person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's knife in my hand, the knife might have cut the carpet by itself. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I will cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm unlucky that way.
What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's very cute! It's small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her cabinet, so I was very excited when she gave it to me!
But the cabinet is a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But Angela is only fifteen, so I think I'll be in my small room for a long time. I don't really mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried to fit Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it...
Then I had an idea. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this "lateral thinking." I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house. They secretly take things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' view, not the humans', which made filming more difficult. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series was shown, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully strange. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act at all. One important thing for me was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was filmed with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t very accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was pretty successful in showing the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. I wonder how long it will take before things get crazy. It always happens: fake smiles, people pretending to be friends, and asking for free tickets to my dad's concerts. "Everything's going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we're staying for good. I chose this school because I want to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal.
I walk into the school's main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the school secretary. "Name?" she asks, not looking very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused. "Oh," she says and types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That's one good thing. Not many people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it's printing," she says. Then she hands me the paper. English Literature is my first class. Cool, I like English. It's my favorite subject. I'll be late, though. English is in Room 214, on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn't get lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I quietly slip in and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She looks at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! No one will suspect anything now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn't have worn these. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says. "Here." The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them, she tells us about the books we need to read this year and gives us time to talk to each other. All teachers should do this. "So why'd you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many choices. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out soon anyway. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. "He's an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I'm Becca, by the way." And she doesn't seem to care. Excellent.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do many things. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being a teenager in America is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough anymore. If you don't have big goals, people might think you are lazy. 
Teenager Kristen Loose says, "People, especially adults, forget how much pressure teenagers have these days. We have lots of homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home. We also try to have a social life." Even though these pressures are normal for teenagers today, people still have negative ideas about them. The media often shows teenagers as lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might be like this, it is not fair to say all teenagers are the same.
Kristen Loose says that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She thinks this is not true. She admits she keeps her phone close most of the time, but not just for fun. It helps her and other teenagers manage their busy lives. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable all the time, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their work anywhere. They might listen to language lessons instead of music on the way to school. Schoolwork and activities now need attention all the time, not just at school, which makes teenagers very busy.
Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the nine hours of sleep recommended each night. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teenagers get enough sleep. Also, 28% of teenagers said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are so tired.
Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen does not spend much of this time on social media or TV. She likes to volunteer. "People think teenagers only care about themselves," Olsen says. But she enjoys helping others and making a positive impact in her school and community.
In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will still be proving it wrong and making the world better. There will be a new generation of students who will make a big impact before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a small town in the US near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has sent more than fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project with a fun twist: it’s part astronomy experiment and part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to launch a high-altitude balloon to try to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside, there is a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer to check temperature changes. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find the lunch box later. A gas tank, given by someone from a nearby state, is used to fill the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy drove seven hours to get the gas tank. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time to launch. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they count down, and the balloon starts to rise. Some of them run and follow it with flashlights until they can't see it anymore. There is a quiet and a shared feeling of wonder. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside and look at the clear sky. It’s hard to believe they are just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with about 4 million people. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep quickly. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon gets bigger until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is not much land with people around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. ‘To me, finding the lunch box is a big part of the program,’ says the group’s leader, who notes they’ve lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. Then they had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or in a tall tree. ‘These students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild and dangerous to some is just normal life to them.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s also a chance to talk about atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. And it’s another adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that she wasn't interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest started by accident. Her younger brother was very interested in dinosaurs, a common interest for kids, but Chloe wasn't. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. This article amazed her, and she realized she wanted to learn more about it.
Chloe was curious about how she got support because Palaeontology wasn't a common career choice for young people then. She remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous. Chloe was nervous at first, even though Matt was known to be friendly. She worried he might think she was just a kid bothering him with questions. But he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.
Chloe talks about how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. She admits that films like Jurassic Park have made people more interested in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She thinks movies often show palaeontologists as either strange geniuses or awkward people who can't relate to others. Films don't show what their work is really like.
Chloe's job is very varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. She also thinks it's important to explain science to the public. She likes to talk to young people about science to help them understand it better. Talking about dinosaurs can get kids excited about the natural world and help them learn about other sciences.
Chloe worked on the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs. She says the program makers knew what they were doing, and she was there to give advice if needed. She mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived in the same time period. The program was successful because it showed dinosaurs in a new, realistic way.
Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of adventure and discovery. Even though our world seems smaller now, prehistoric creatures remind us there's still more to learn. Palaeontology is like a form of time travel.

I'm going to say this once: when you're traveling by car with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" And when you finally arrive, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So, if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" I'm sure no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who hear that question over and over during long car trips. 
Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, mom or dad is there to give you juice boxes and cookies, change the radio station, and make sure everything goes smoothly. 
"Are we there yet?" I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. I put my foot on his side, and soon we're fighting. The driver and the person in the front seat separate us and tell Tim to stay in his own seat. Things calm down for a while, and the scenery continues to pass by. 
Later, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the window isn't open. It's Tim, blowing air on me from his side. He's not touching me, so he thinks he's not doing anything wrong. I get angry, Tim gets in trouble, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again—for now. 
Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. When we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yes, we're here. Get out of the car." We say, "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." He replies, "Oh, maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. 
You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move far away from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is no, you're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and come back. Zuzi explains that they wanted to create a place where people can connect without using phones or gadgets. She believes it's natural for people to be together and talk to each other.
The games in their café are called 'Eurogames'. These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, now called Catan, created by Klaus Teuber from Germany. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players work as a team to win or lose together, which encourages more social interaction. 
One popular co-operative Eurogame is Pandemic, created by Matt Leacock from North America. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by another Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He remembers playing it with friends and feeling excited, even if they lost. He wanted to create a game that gave the same feeling.
Leacock loved board games since he was a child, even though he often felt disappointed by them. With help from his uncle, he started designing better games. Pandemic became very successful, and its next version included more storytelling, similar to video games where characters develop and the world changes.
Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped the success of modern board games. Many people now play games on their phones, making them more open to playing board games too. Ben Hogg, who works for a games company, says that almost everyone with a smartphone plays games.
In the past, video games allowed people to play together in the same room. But now, many video games are played online, where players are not physically together. This has made some people look for games they can play with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that board games are more than just fun. In our online world, they offer a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many challenges. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him start playing the guitar. The only radio station he heard at home was for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He says he was 12 before he heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, ‘With tennis, I was at a high level, but it was not what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. It was too much hard work.’ At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to make music, saying he wrote lyrics in economics lessons and played the piano every day. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed; if not, he had to get a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. But record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend. In the end, he became famous behind the scenes, not on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. Fame and fortune did not come. He says, ‘In my artist career, I was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, I was in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he found success. He says, ‘I’d like to think I am one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to.’ This helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that writing songs for the charts is okay. He asks, ‘Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should write songs that are amazing and likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write big hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write number one songs and has the talent to do it. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. He says, ‘When I go into the studio, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.’

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online, but people who don't watch online videos of bike stunts might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist.' This means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online.
I met Tony at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys knew who he was, and even older people came to say he was 'an absolute legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, Tony explained what he wanted to do, and I wasn't always sure he could do it. But he did, and when I praised him, he didn't seem very excited. Even though he is famous online, Tony doesn't like being a celebrity. He says, 'I find it hard to be social. I know it's important to talk to fans, but I prefer doing things instead of talking about them.'
Tony's fame comes from social media and new camera technology. He says, 'This technology helps people like me make a living.' But he also feels that everyone is always looking at screens, and he doesn't like that. Still, he is happy because he can make money from what used to be just a hobby.
From my experience with top athletes, I know two things are important to become great: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent. In risky sports, you need mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on easy obstacles. But he got up and tried again until he succeeded.
Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some say he takes too many risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport. They don't know the technical details or that he gets advice from experts to stay safe. Tony is careful about risks. He says, 'Some people never get scared, but they shouldn't do these sports. It's good to know the dangers. Some people can't get over fear, but I can. I plan and prepare a lot. Sometimes I ride around to get ready before a new stunt. I know I can't lose my nerve before I jump. If I fully commit, I'm fine.'

One of the most interesting changes in education in the UK and around the world is encouraging students to start doing research early in their studies. This idea is that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists, but it is a natural way to learn and build skills. Research skills are useful not only in school but also in jobs because they help us think about the world and do our work better.
As a student, you help create knowledge. You don't just learn and repeat it; you make it. Making knowledge means asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are part of what we call research.
Research can be very complex and done by experts, but it can also be simple and part of everyday life. For example, when you plan a holiday, grow plants, fix things at home, or choose the right music system, you are doing research. At college, you are expected to have an enquiring mind, find problems and questions, explore information, and create your own ideas.
Some students might find this difficult because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as something you get from teachers and books without questioning. But in the UK, US, and many other places, it is important to question what you learn and who teaches it. This might seem challenging, but it is a key part of learning.
Critical thinking is very important in research. We need to not just repeat what we read but think about it, test it, and see if it makes sense. We should not just accept information without questioning it.

Cities have always been places where people think and create new ideas. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In modern Paris, artist Pablo Picasso talked about art in cafés. But living in a city is not always easy. The same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. Cities are full of creativity, but they can also be stressful and unnatural.
Scientists are now studying how living in a city affects our brains. They found that city life can make our thinking less sharp. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees. Even a small view of nature can help our brains because it gives us a break from city life.
More people now live in cities than ever before. Instead of open spaces, we live in crowded areas with many strangers. This can affect our mental and physical health. Walking in a busy city street, our brains have to pay attention to many things: people, traffic, and the city layout. This constant attention is tiring because our brains have to decide what to focus on and what to ignore.
Natural places are different. They don't need as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, created by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He said that being in nature helps our brains relax and recover. Nature captures our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens.
Long ago, people like philosophers and landscape architects knew cities could be harmful. They tried to bring nature into cities. Parks like Central Park in New York give people a break from city life. A well-designed park can help our brains work better in just a few minutes. While people try many things to improve brain function, like energy drinks or changing office designs, simply walking in nature is very effective.
Despite the problems of city life, cities keep growing. Even with technology, cities are still places of new ideas. Research shows that the busy and crowded parts of cities, which can make us lose focus, also help create new ideas. The many social interactions in cities lead to creativity. Just like 18th-century London, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are centers of innovation.
The challenge is to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its benefits. Because sometimes, people still want to leave nature and go back to the city.

Where should we look for the mind? Many people think that the mind is only inside our heads. Today, we have advanced machines that can take pictures of the brain to show this. But I believe that the study of the mind should not stop at the brain. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, that objects and tools also play a part in how we think. Archaeology shows that things like stone tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and in shaping the mind. So, I suggest that what is outside the head can also be part of the mind.
It is easy to think that the mind and the brain are the same because most studies look at people without the objects they usually use. This makes sense for scientists who study the brain because they need to use special machines. But this means we often forget that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I am not saying that the brain is not important for thinking, but I want to show that the mind is more than just the brain. It is helpful to think that human intelligence spreads out into the world and culture around us.
This is where my new idea, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET looks at how objects become part of our thinking, like when we make numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool. It also studies how these ways have changed over time and what that means for how we think. This gives us a new understanding of what minds are and what they are made of.
Think of a blind person with a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The stick and the person become one, showing how the mind and objects can be connected. The stick helps the blind person feel the world, turning touch into sight. The brain treats the stick as part of the body. This example shows that human intelligence can change a lot by using new tools and technology.
I see the human mind as always changing and evolving. Throughout history, from the first stone tools to the internet, tools have helped humans understand and interact with the world. For humans, tools are not just for getting food, like a monkey using a stick, but for learning and exploring. This is why humans make things and why those things help shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity, meaning our minds change as they interact with the world.
MET offers a new way to understand how different tools, from ancient axes to modern smartphones, have helped define and change who we are and how we think. Technology that changes the mind might sound like science fiction, but humans have been using it since we first evolved.

Photography is one of the most important inventions that changed how we see the world. In the United States, photography quickly became a big part of the culture. It was used in many areas like science, industry, art, and entertainment. Historians say photography might be the greatest contribution of the US to the visual arts. Photography became very important in the US, and to understand its impact, we need to look at its start in the mid-19th century.
Why was photography so popular? First, it was a mechanical process, which matched the US's love for technology and change. Just like steam power and railroads made the world feel smaller, photography brought images of the world into people's homes quickly. Second, the camera was a tool to show personal and national identity. It helped people create and keep memories of themselves and their families, even if these memories were a bit idealized. Third, photographs were realistic and matched the US artists' focus on everyday life.
Photographs draw attention to what the photographer wants us to see. They are records of events, people, and things, showing what was in front of the camera. This gives photographs a sense of objectivity. However, because a person takes the photo, it also shows their point of view, or subjectivity. People often think photographs are a 'universal language' because they recognize the subject. But understanding a photograph is more complex. We need to consider the context, like captions or where the photo is shown, to understand its meaning.
To understand a photograph historically, we should think about why it was made and how people first saw it. The same photo can have different meanings in different places and times. In recent decades, artists like Andy Warhol have used photographs in their art in many ways. Photography has become an important part of art, working together with painting to show how we see the world.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have thoughts and feelings, so we have some idea of what mental life means. Psychology can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, but it is mostly about humans. James believed human psychology includes thoughts, feelings, the physical world around us, and how we understand these things. Our understanding is personal and comes from our own experiences, which may not always match scientific facts. 
We often act like amateur psychologists when we give opinions on why people behave in certain ways, like feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems occur when people see things differently. Formal psychology tries to find the best explanations for these situations. Psychologists help us tell the difference between personal opinions and scientific facts. 
Psychology studies the mind and brain, but we don't fully understand the brain's role in our thoughts and actions. Psychologists learn more by observing behavior and making guesses about what happens inside us. Studying psychology is challenging because we can't see the mind directly. We have to guess what is happening based on behavior, like solving a puzzle. Psychologists use careful observation and logical thinking to understand complex interactions. 
The goals of psychology are to describe, understand, predict, and control behavior. Once these goals are met, psychology can help improve people's lives. For example, it can help teach children to read better, design safer machines, and support people with emotional problems. 
Psychological questions have been around for a long time, but scientific study of them began only about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or looking into one's own mind, to find answers. However, this method has limits. As Sir Francis Galton said, it only shows a small part of what the brain does automatically. William James compared it to trying to see darkness by quickly turning on a light. Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on observing others' behavior rather than just their own thoughts.

In a simple building in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum shows products that nobody wanted to buy, like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and Carol Sherry is in charge of it. She believes each product tells a sad story about the people who designed and sold it. 
The museum is surprising because it makes money, even though it shows products that failed. You might think companies would keep their own collections of failed products, but they usually don't. Many business leaders visit the museum because they don't like to think about their failures and didn't keep samples of their own unsuccessful products.
The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, who used to work in marketing, wanted to collect a library of consumer products, not just failures. Since the 1960s, he bought a sample of every new product he found. He discovered that most products fail, so his collection mostly includes unsuccessful ones.
Today's culture often focuses on being positive, which might explain why these failed products exist. People in meetings might not realize a product will fail, or they might keep spending money on it to try to make it succeed. They often don't spend time figuring out what went wrong.
This focus on optimism is common in the self-help world, where people believe that imagining success can make it happen. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot found that people tend to think things will go better than they actually might. Her research shows that people who are not depressed often have an overly positive view of their ability to change things.
Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen studied whether thinking positively about the future helps. Her research found that imagining success can actually reduce motivation to achieve goals. For example, people who thought they would have a great week at work ended up doing less.
Psychologist Carol Dweck says our beliefs about ability affect how we handle failure. Some people think ability is fixed and can't change, while others believe it can grow with effort. People who think ability is fixed find failure very upsetting because they see it as proof they aren't good enough. On the other hand, people who believe in growth see failure as a chance to improve. Dweck compares this to weight training: muscles get stronger by being pushed to their limits. Having a growth mindset is a happier way to live, whether or not it leads to success.

Sports teams often do better when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know the answer, but sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main reasons for this are science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what helps players perform their best, and they have many ideas about home advantage. On the other hand, people who invest money in sports wonder if home advantage should matter. They think that if players are paid well, they should play well anywhere.
What about the fans? Would it matter if a team like Manchester United played some home games in another country to reach more fans? It would matter to British fans who believe their support helps the team win. Fans often think that when they cheer loudly, it leads to goals. But they forget the times when their cheering didn't lead to success.
There is one thing that fans do that seems to affect the game. They often try to influence the referee. In an experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows that referees might avoid making decisions that would upset the home crowd.
Studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home football teams in England won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and stadiums are very similar. However, these changes happened recently, and home advantage still varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. This might be because basketball relies more on teamwork, which is stronger at home.
Another reason for home advantage could be related to players' testosterone levels. Studies found that these levels are higher before home games, which might be a natural urge to defend their home ground. This was seen in the Rugby World Cup, where home teams won against stronger opponents by showing determination and aggression. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

"‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is important to athletes and their coaches. The saying is interesting because its meaning is not clear. Player didn’t really mean he got lucky; he meant that practice makes him better. This idea is part of the nature-nurture debate, which asks if talent is something you are born with or something you learn. 
Many people believe practice is more important than natural talent. This idea comes from psychologist Anders Ericsson, who said that you can become an expert in anything with 10,000 hours of practice. This theory became popular through books like Malcolm Gladwell’s "Outliers" and others like "Talent Is Overrated." These books say practice is the most important thing, and 10,000 hours is enough to become an expert.
However, in his book, Epstein argues that this is not always true. He shows many examples to explain his point. He says that studies often only look at successful people and try to explain why they are successful. Epstein asks if there are other ways to understand why some people have certain skills and others don’t. He explores how much of talent is natural and how much comes from environment, support, and hard work.
Epstein travels around the world to find answers, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to Alaska. In Alaska, he learns that the husky dogs’ drive in a sled race might be partly genetic. This suggests that determination might also be something you are born with, not just a choice. 
Epstein talks about the difference between ‘hardware’ (natural talent) and ‘software’ (learned skills). He believes both are important for top athletes. He doesn’t ignore the importance of training or environment. For example, he suggests that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest runner. But Epstein also looks at cases where natural talent is very important. 
He also discusses race and gender. He asks why men and women compete separately in sports if only practice matters. Sometimes, the simplest questions are the most important."

A recent international report shows that many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why children today feel this way. In her book, "Kith," she explains that children spend too much time indoors, watching TV or using computers, and have lost touch with nature. Griffiths believes this is the main problem. Other studies agree, showing that children would be happier if they could play outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their childhoods fondly, when they played outside all day, which they think was healthier than how children live now. However, these adults are the ones who have made life more protective for their children, worrying about safety and risks.
Griffiths argues that fear of danger keeps kids indoors, which benefits companies selling toys and gadgets. She also criticizes the trend of giving children medicine for being restless or making them wear goggles for playground games. She questions how common these rules are but expresses her strong opinions clearly. Griffiths also talks about the importance of childhood freedom, like in fairy tales and school rules. However, she sometimes takes her ideas too far, comparing modern treatment of children to racism, which seems exaggerated.
Griffiths is very romantic about children, seeing them in an ideal way. She believes children should have freedom to explore and take risks, learning from small accidents to avoid bigger ones later. But she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are small. Also, not all children want to be adventurous. Some are naturally shy and prefer staying home. The real issue might be forcing all children to live the same way, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not because of my education. Most life problems cannot be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play. Those that have more to learn play more. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, and moral lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is important for economic success. We do not need people to follow instructions like robots or do routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate problems, we will have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his work 'combinatorial play.' He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam.
