We cannot teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling that focuses on set questions and answers. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring for them, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit if they want. This makes play democratic. School has become harder: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and there is more pressure for high grades. Outside school, adult-led sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must solve children's problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They are due to social factors like parents' fears, warnings from experts, less community, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change this trend. We must give childhood back to children. They need to play and explore to grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn help them connect directly with employers. In the past, people had to do things like stand outside an office with a "hire me" sign to get noticed. But with more access to employers, there is also a bigger chance to make mistakes.
For example, a young person in the US contacted a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts, and the young person thought they could help him get a job. However, the executive was not happy with this request. She did not want to share her contacts with a stranger and sent a harsh rejection note, which became very popular online. Many people who saw the note were shocked, and the executive might regret how she wrote it. But this situation can teach young people to be more careful when using social media for work. It shows that social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly.
There is an irony here because social media sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of young people's social lives for years. When I was a teenager, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to impress others and try new things. You could talk to someone online for hours and then ignore them at school. You could change your image with a new profile picture or song on Facebook. But using social media for work is very different, and some young people do not see the difference. We learned to be bold and confident online, which might be why some of us still act this way. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you can impress employers on LinkedIn. We need to understand that what we learned about social media as teenagers does not work for job hunting. We must meet employers' expectations to succeed in the job market.
One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers are too familiar and seem arrogant on professional networking sites. This makes older people think of us as an "entitled generation." But in reality, many young people are desperate to find jobs, which is why they use social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt their chances of getting a job, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable workers.
So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach gives you a better chance of getting a positive response. Avoid sending impersonal, mass emails, and keep your tone humble to avoid offending the person you are contacting. Remember, social media can be a great way to make useful connections, but you need to be careful to avoid closing doors.

'Anyone who says they can predict the future of newspapers is either lying or mistaken. If you look at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the number of people buying most UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, the Pew Research Centre says that newspapers are now the main news source for only 26% of people, compared to 45% in 2001. Many people predict that printed newspapers will disappear in 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist said books and theatre were finished, and newspapers would become the most important part of social life. But theatre survived newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has done well even with TV, and cinema has stayed popular despite videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records are popular again, with sales up 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media too, but it took centuries for them to become the main way to get news. This happened because it became possible and affordable to produce news for many people in the mid-19th century, thanks to the steam press, railway, and telegraph. Also important was the idea that everything is always changing, and we need regular updates, which was not common in medieval times. Now, we expect change. In medieval times, people only noticed the changing seasons and big events like famine or disease, which they couldn't predict. Life was seen as repeating cycles, as writer Alain de Botton says. Journalism as a job you could live on didn't really exist before the 19th century. Even then, there was no clear reason why people needed news regularly. Publishing newspapers regularly and in a fixed format can be a problem. Online news lets readers check news when they want. Search engines and algorithms help us find news that interests us. When big news happens, online news can update us minute by minute. Mistakes can be fixed quickly, and there is no limit on space for stories. This is very different from newspapers. But many online news providers focus on being first with the news and getting lots of comments, which can add to confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. In some ways, we are going back to that. Newspapers have not always been good at explaining how the world works. They might disappear. Or, as the internet makes us feel like we live in a chaotic world, newspapers might find a way to help us understand things better.'

If humans were comfortable under the moon and stars, we would enjoy walking in the dark, just like many animals that are active at night. But we are daytime creatures, with eyes made for sunlight. This is a basic part of who we are, even if we don't often think about it. We have changed the night by filling it with light, similar to how we control a river with a dam. This has benefits but also causes problems, known as light pollution, which scientists are just starting to study. Light pollution happens mostly because of poor lighting design, which lets artificial light shine into the sky instead of focusing it on the ground. This extra light changes the natural darkness of night, affecting many living things, including us. It can disturb activities like migration, reproduction, and feeding. 
In the past, the idea of 'light pollution' would not have made sense. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800. It was the most populated city on Earth, with nearly a million people using candles, torches, and lanterns for light. Only a few houses had gas lights, and there were no public gaslights in the streets yet. From a few miles away, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. 
We have lit up the night as if it were empty, but it is not. Many animals, especially mammals, are active at night. Light is a strong force in nature and attracts many species. For example, songbirds and seabirds can be drawn to bright lights on land or at sea, flying around them until they are exhausted. Birds migrating at night might crash into tall, brightly lit buildings, and young birds on their first journey are especially at risk. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd times because of artificial light.
People used to think light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need a clear night sky for their work. Most of us don't need a perfect view of the stars, but we do need darkness. Darkness is important for our health, just like light. Changing our natural sleep patterns can cause health problems. The regular cycle of day and night is a natural part of life, and disturbing it is like changing our balance. In the end, we are affected by light pollution just like animals near bright lights. By creating so much light, we have lost touch with our natural and cultural heritage – the stars and the natural rhythm of day and night. Light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe, which we can best understand by looking at the night sky with the Milky Way above us.

The founder of a big international company recently said that his company will stop keeping track of how much paid holiday time employees take. This idea came from an internet company that did something similar. The founder got the idea from an email from his daughter, which was shared in many newspapers. Some people think this announcement is just a way to make the company look good, but we should ask: is this idea practical?
The internet company and the big international company are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the big company has 50,000 employees and many different services like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want as long as it doesn’t hurt the business" might work better in a smaller company where people know each other’s work better. In a big company, it’s harder to know if your absence will cause problems.
The founder of the big company said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work is up to date and their absence won’t harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? Even if you finish your work before a holiday, there will always be more work waiting when you return. This is just how taking leave works. People might feel guilty about taking time off, which can lead to stress and lower productivity over time.
There might also be pressure from coworkers and office gossip about who is taking time off and for how long. In many companies, especially in the corporate world, there is a culture of working late. This could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave, where people compete for promotions. If the feeling of safety that comes with having a set amount of leave is removed, people might feel they can’t take the leave they need because they don’t want to seem lazy. They would no longer have their legal right to rely on.
Modern technology lets us get work messages anytime and anywhere, making it hard to separate work from free time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees asked how this new way of working could fit with the old time-off policy. They wondered why the company should track time off if it couldn’t track work hours accurately. But if there are no set work hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might feel like they are always being watched, which could be harmful.
Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers have a right to a minimum amount of paid leave because rest is important for their health. The benefits like better morale, creativity, and productivity that are expected from the unlimited leave policy can happen without affecting worker well-being. I am not sure if letting employees "take as much holiday as they want" is really what the company wants or if it will actually happen.

Journal-based peer review is a process where experts check a scientific paper before it is published. This is to make sure the research is good and not flawed. Scientists often say this process is important to keep trust in published research. However, reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to ensure the research is trustworthy? The answer is both yes and no. 
The world of scientific publishing is changing. I still believe in peer review, but things are shifting. Preprints, which are drafts of papers shared online without peer review, are becoming more popular. They allow new research to be shared quickly so others can read, critique, and build on it. Publishing in journals has become more about gaining fame and advancing careers, which can affect the motivations of authors and reviewers. Scientists compete to publish in top journals, which can lead to cutting corners and leaving out important data. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is good enough for a journal, not just if it is good. 
These issues are known, but few people want to change the current system. Preprints might be a solution because they don't require a big change. Although preprints have been around for twenty years, they are not widely used. This is partly because scientists think journals won't accept papers that have been shared as preprints. There is also a fear that publishing without peer review will lead to bad science, but this hasn't happened yet. 
Preprints are not peer-reviewed, but they are open for critique by a global community. Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience with preprints. Her paper critiqued another paper, which is hard to do in traditional journals. With preprints, the original authors could respond, and all comments were public. This way, readers can judge the quality of the arguments. Even if a journal rejects the paper, the preprint and comments are still available, so the work is not wasted.
Preprint archives allow for global scientific discussions that used to happen only between individuals. They can also share negative results, which are important but often ignored by journals focused on new discoveries. Preprints increase how often papers are read and cited, showing they are effective for sharing research. By using the internet's openness, preprints help focus on the research itself, not just where it is published.

When I ask my literature students what a poem is, they often say it’s like ‘a painting in words’. These answers don’t usually satisfy me or them. One day, I asked a group to pick an object and write one paragraph describing it like a scientist would, and another paragraph from the object’s point of view, calling it ‘Poem’. Here’s what one student wrote:
Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I’m a device that helps people breathe. I’m only used in emergencies and only for a short time. Most people will never need me.
The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise was fun and led to a good discussion. When I was in school, poetry didn’t make much sense to me. I thought every poem was a confusing puzzle that stopped me from really understanding and feeling. After school, most people find poetry less interesting. Sometimes you see a poem, and it stands out because it’s not like regular writing. It almost challenges you to read it, and often you feel let down because it seems boring or hard to understand at first. Still, you feel good for trying.
What do we want from the poems we read? Isn’t a poem supposed to be full of deep feelings, beautiful images, gentle thoughts, or sharp humor? The answer might seem to be yes. But if we want to cry, we watch movies; for information or strong opinions, we read online articles. Novels let us escape to other worlds, paintings please our eyes, and music – well, nothing beats the mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody. But there is one thing a poem can offer: ambiguity, or uncertainty. Everyday life is full of it, just like reading a poem can be. But these ideas still don’t explain what a poem really is.
If you search online for ‘poem’, it takes you to ‘poetry’: ‘a form of literary art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language’. This is a fancy way to say it, but it doesn’t show the word’s roots. ‘Poem’ comes from the Greek word poí?ma, meaning ‘a thing made,’ and a poet is ‘a maker of things.’ So if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes say poems are like wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or like machines – carefully made by humans – depending on their view. But these comparisons don’t always work. The best part of trying to define a poem through comparison is the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It helps us think differently and see common things in a new way.
Thinking of a poem as a mental object is not hard, especially if we think about how song lyrics can get stuck in our heads. The mix of words and music is powerful, like schoolyard rhymes such as ‘Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me.’ But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a newspaper or magazine page, looking right at you: A poem can touch us like nothing else, even though, as ink on paper, it does the same as the prose around it. What about all the empty space around the poem – space that could be used for a longer article or ad? A poem is written and rewritten like an article, story, or novel, but it doesn’t become a product to sell. Publishers write press releases and send out review copies of poetry books, but few expect them to make money. A poem is not made for the market, but for itself. Because of its special place in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. It cost £70, which was a lot of money back then. My wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, I have enjoyed finding every brooch and coin because it makes me feel connected to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much.
One dull February afternoon, I had some free time and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot that mostly had old farming tools. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it but couldn't leave without checking. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a round, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleared more dirt, I saw it was a thick, beautifully patterned loop. I stopped and stared, then remembered to breathe. It looked like the Great Torc, a famous object from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a twisted necklace made of gold and silver. Each end has a gold ring like the one I found.
I took it to the car and kept looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in ages. I called Marion and showed her. She stopped and asked, "What is it?" I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been robbed, but I was worried. Later, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.
The law says you must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc before giving it up, so I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I put the torc on his desk. He turned, still talking, then stopped mid-sentence. The torc was checked and later sold to my local council. It is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just money. It's something I saved for the nation. People ask if I will stop detecting now that I've found something amazing. But those brooches and coins are still interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn't stop fishing. There's always a chance of catching a bigger fish tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things to do when I travel, but I don't talk about it much because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends tell me about their busy travel plans, full of activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. I wonder what they would think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rain and lazy mornings in Italian beds. Sleeping better is a nice part of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. There were noisy birds nearby, but it didn't bother me. Away from home, in a new place with different smells and sounds, I could sleep deeply and have dreams. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I think there's more to it than just relaxing. I believe sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we see, hear, and smell new things. We experience different cultures, music, and landscapes. While sleeping, we process all these new experiences. That's why sleep feels more intense when we travel. Sleep also changes with each place we visit. People often worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs is harder than changing time zones. For example, on the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to their sleep schedule. Once I do, I feel like I truly belong there. I remember a day in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, we all felt sleepy and lay down on hammocks and sofas. I realized why they had so many pillows on the floor. I joined them and experienced the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I didn't just sleep; I shared a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is special because I remember it. Being in a different place with new smells and sounds makes sleep feel luxurious. If "slow travel" means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then sleep is the slowest activity. Maybe I should stop feeling guilty and tell my friends that sleeping while traveling is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one looks best on you," she said kindly to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face like a bulldog. "But it is so boring," she said. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little hat will make me stand out." She touched the red and black small top hat on her head. "Yes," she said, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change the woman's mind. Smiling, she agreed that the woman would stand out at the wedding. She thought about her own daughter, Jen. It was Jen's thirtieth birthday today, and they were having a family party. It had been a while since everyone was together, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious to meet Jen's friend, who they knew nothing about. Her husband Jeff had quickly pointed out when Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie. "Tattie," Jeff said, "What kind of name is that?" "It's short for Tatiana," Mia replied. "I think it’s nice." "It sounds pretentious," Jeff said. He didn't like anything showy or fake. He also didn't like Mia's way of being too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat. He might have even said that a trash can lid would look better on her. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite." An hour later, Mia closed the shop and went into Medlar House through the back door. Her walk from work took only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia decided to turn the empty barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think people want hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends that finding the perfect hat for a special occasion was hard, so she was sure there was a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her make a website, Mia’s Hats was a success. Women came from far away to her shop in the village of Little Pelham. In a friendly place, they could try on many hats to find the right one. With changing rooms available, she encouraged customers to bring their outfits so everything matched. She recently started selling handbags and costume jewelry too.

It's a long way from London to Atlanta. In his new American home, Lawrence Okoye thinks about his amazing sports journey. He is confident but surprised by how far he has come—from an Olympic discus final to a new challenge. Even though he has never played American football before, Lawrence might be chosen for a big USA team. In Atlanta, he is learning about his new position in the sport. It seems unbelievable that a 21-year-old from London could be picked for one of the top American teams, but Lawrence is used to surprising people. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on discus instead. In just 20 months, he became the fourth-best discus thrower in the world. Lawrence first went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training to prepare for the world championships. He says, "American football was in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. I thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then." After arriving in America, he read about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, he thought he might be good enough to try out. "Pretty much," he says. "I went online and applied." Was he nervous about competing with experienced players? "No," he says. "I don't get nervous about many things." Lawrence is not very talkative, but he believes in his abilities. His test results were so good that he was seen as the most impressive player. "I was very happy to hear that," he says, showing a bit of pride. But he is also careful. Lawrence has no experience in American football. How can he make it into an NFL team? "Coaches say I have the right skills. It's about how hard I work," he replies. Is he relaxed while waiting to hear if he is selected? "I am. There's no pressure on me. Many people think I'll be picked, but I'm not worried." This calm attitude might come from his Olympic experience, where he finished last in the discus final. He seems to have moved on and is happy he made it to the final with a great last throw. "That was an amazing day," he says. "The final didn't go as I wanted, but that's part of sport. I can always go back to it." After the Olympics, some thought the big event affected him. Lawrence doesn't comment on this. An NFL player's minimum salary is over $400,000 a year, so the money is a big reason to try. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his talent, wouldn't it be better to focus on one sport? "I understand why someone would say that," he answers. "I'm trying to do something I've dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn't work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I've made has been thought through."

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out of the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green made me feel better because, even though it was mid-September, it had not started snowing in Siberia yet. I saw no signs of people, just mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow. He was flying to a remote area to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as bad as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I told him I believed there was a road, though not many people used it now. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend called Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unsure and said one word, "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, but I didn't mention that I was on a tight budget because my trip was self-funded. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at low prices. I wasn't sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman's over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students sitting tiredly in their seats. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer kept talking. I was thinking hard about a question. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy writing, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to manage my classes, the job was good for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and fulfilling. Plus, there were long holidays to go on adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I used these holidays to meet Al. He had become very adventurous after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: to cycle around the world. Since that first ride, Al had been taking on bigger challenges. This trip around the world by bike was his biggest challenge so far. Sometimes he thought the ride or the road would be too much for him. Even though it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an amazing adventure, finding that he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the people who said he couldn't do it. He was doing something that scared him almost every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through tall pylons, which are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to take part in this race. 
An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first form said I was in good health, and the second said I would empty my pockets because small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I also learned that I needed to stay aware of my surroundings. I was told, "The horizon is your best friend," and the pilot would tell me where to look. I was also asked to promise to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.
Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything. When we were moving down the runway, I tried not to touch the important steering pedals with my feet or the switches with my hands. I decided I would not relax and enjoy the flight, even though I was told to. In high-speed acrobatic flying, you need to stay calm and focused. You have to tense up and relax at the right times. Panicking is not a good idea.
As we started down the runway, Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and two seconds later, we turned sharply to the right. It was a quick and strong move, and I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned left and dived, leaving my stomach high in the air and my lungs feeling tight. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, flying between two pylons at 400 km per hour. My excitement was cut short by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even started the acrobatics yet.
For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane. My hand was shaking so much that the plane shook too because it was very responsive. Then Dario said something, and I asked him to repeat it. Instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I replied. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle in the air. Some people might find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters, but I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, when we were upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw some fields.
The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what the pilots experience during a race. To show this, Dario started eating sandwiches as soon as we landed. I didn't eat for hours, and that night, I dreamed about doing loops over and over again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you have ever seen amazing videos of polar bears in a nature documentary, he probably filmed them. He likes it best when the temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first love, and he learned how to survive in cold places. His big chance came when a TV crew came to Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. ‘I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.’ He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. ‘I started at a good time. When I began, not many people had been to the Antarctic. There were people who filmed coral, elephants, and chimpanzees. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were waiting to be filmed.’ The camera and communication technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. ‘It is certainly easier to film today. If you filmed something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can film a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You filmed less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.’ ‘My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.’ Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy job. It is a world of polar bears and is very dangerous. Usually -32C in April, the wind is strong and carrying cameras in the deep snow is very hard. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. ‘We find a new hole and wait. We move around to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera’s locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye’s very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She’s looking at me but she’s not bothered. I’ve just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can’t get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I’d swear it’s partly in sheer pleasure,’ he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. ‘Clearly it’s their first view of the world … It’s show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.’ Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim in very cold water and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for a new and even more challenging expedition. Explorers are confident and determined people, and Pen is no different. This time, there is a lot more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre journey to the North Pole. They will take detailed measurements of the ice's thickness and density. No one has done this before, and the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. Pen was trained for this kind of work. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tough by sending him out into the cold Scottish mountains with very few clothes. His father loved adventures in the cold, and Pen found he had great physical endurance. Pen is married to Mary, who loves horses and the outdoors. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he is at home because he is often thinking about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horses compete against runners. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. Pen says it is harder to leave them this time. When he last went, his children were one and five years old. He made a mistake by telling his son, "You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister." His son took it very seriously, which was too much pressure. So, Pen plans to have little contact with them while in the Arctic. "If you call them, you remind them how far away you are," he says. Before leaving, he is carefully preparing his equipment. "On the ice, you can't fix things easily," he explains. Ann Daniels, a top polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer, will join him. They will have a team of six people flying in supplies. Being part of a team is more stressful for Pen, and he is also worried about his age. "I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I haven’t trained as much as I’d like," he says. Why? "Organizing things always seems more urgent. So I’m almost afraid of what I’ll ask of myself." Pen believes his mission is important for learning about the Arctic. "Reaching the North Pole was a personal goal," he admits, "and not very useful to others. This time, scientists will benefit from the data, and we’re trying to involve as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and only we can do it," he says. "Our skills, which seemed strange and not useful before, are now very important. Suddenly, we’re useful to society again."

I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is amazing. I had the chance to do more writing, work on TV, and speak to businesses and schools. These activities were great, but I missed having something competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay fit in case I wanted to try for the Olympics again. So, I entered marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about TV presenter Ben Fogle’s invitation: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I have always loved rowing and missed the feeling of the boat moving through the water. But I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked my rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but no one was interested. I knew if I entered, I would want to win, even though it was more of an adventure. Would rowing with Ben help me win? Probably not. But being the underdog with no pressure was interesting. I contacted Ben. He was going to do the race anyway and had found the money for the entry fee and a boat deposit, making the race a real possibility. We talked about the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000 – a lot of money. We thought we had a good chance, but it would still take work to get everything ready. Besides the race costs, I also had to think about losing money from not working. Speaking at business conferences is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete. It’s nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would mean I’d have something new to talk about: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one big lesson was to appreciate the easy life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but looking back, it was simple. I trained almost every day, but the program was set, and there were doctors and dieticians. I worried about what people would think of me racing with a TV presenter. I was concerned it would look like I just wanted to be on TV, instead of choosing a better partner to win. But during our preparations, my worries went away. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about the mind than just rowing. Ben had done the tough Marathon des Sables, spent a lot of time at sea, and lived on a deserted island for a year. But he couldn’t row. I was surprised by how little he knew about rowing, and he was surprised by my lack of patience. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest with Ben about the improvements he needed. I should have known his level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. At 26, I felt restless. I dreamed of the Arctic's cold and empty landscapes, maybe because of the noise and crowds in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to let me work as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, many tourists come for sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm’. It was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They said I could join the team for three months if I knew what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away.
November 6, London On my flight, I try to memorize the names of over 100 huskies, but I feel distracted and nervous. I stop and look out the window instead. People say spring moves north at about 26 km per day, with flowers and leaves opening. But I feel like I see winter moving south, with rivers freezing.
November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus ride north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrive at the farm after dark and am quickly given boots and sent outside. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which gets louder as I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, getting the huskies ready and harnessing them to sleds. The dogs are very excited, pulling hard on the ropes. I can barely hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and we start moving into the dark, with only a head torch for light.
November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I am asked what I can do for the group. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I don’t know. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never used an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, whatever happens, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become hard in freezing conditions. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions, and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds and being pulled by excited huskies. But I feel proud. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe ran past the finish line, the press gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would allow her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists were curious and asked her about emu oil, a natural treatment. Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended it to help heal Radcliffe's injuries from an accident when she ran into a bike while training. Radcliffe says she never really realized how big her achievement was. Looking back, she knows it was a big deal, but at the time, it just felt like what she was supposed to do. She and her team had decided not to set any limits. Their motto was: no limits.
During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent worried if she could keep up the fast pace. He thought she might have to stop the race. Hartmann was angry about this, but he understood that people who didn't know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast.
With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. She had run 41 kilometers very fast but still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." The race director, Dave Bedford, said he didn't think anyone would come close to that time soon. Radcliffe thought, "I'm going to come back and do it next year." Sadly, that didn't happen.
After the race, people wanted to know how Radcliffe, who ran with an awkward style, beat the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had stayed with Radcliffe for weeks, giving her daily sessions to help with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle that level of pain. She would make me work so hard that I had to ice my thumbs afterward."
Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no "Hello Gerard, do you want a cup of tea?" He barely got in the door before starting a two-hour session. Paula pushed him to give his best, which made her so good. During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became upset.
Can Radcliffe explain why no one has beaten her record? "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought it might happen with Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner). Maybe it's because people are racing each other more than racing themselves." What does she mean? "That mental way of never slowing down, even when you've won the race, probably pushed me to it because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always: 'keep pushing as hard as you can.'"
Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the best of her career. She would never run as fast again. However, she left a lasting legacy. Many women were inspired to start long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, "In Search of Perfection," came out, I didn't know how people would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' in Britain. I believed our show was a new and exciting part of that change. But I was worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques, but also history, memories, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I didn't need to worry. The show was a success and led to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether it's about the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often a real one, with travel and meeting new people. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest book, where you travel around the world to meet amazing people, like a man who makes the best golden pasta. These people have spent years trying to reach their own idea of perfection. Perfection is different for everyone. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was hard, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish wasn't included. But after long meetings, the TV team and I made a list that had something for everyone. This showed me that everyone has their own idea of what perfection is, based on their feelings, memories, and surroundings. I knew from the start that I wouldn't say the recipes were the 'best.' But I thought that by using my skills and talking to food experts, I could find out what made these dishes special. The dictionary says 'perfection' means being perfect, but it also means improving through trying new things. The TV series let me explore new foods, people, and places, which was very exciting. Finding the best ingredients took me all over the world. Some of my adventures included visiting a factory that had the wrong tomatoes and a dairy farm that wasn't good enough to film. I also tried new techniques, like hand-milking a cow to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital machine, and almost burning my house down trying to make a perfect pizza.

We were still far from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise and went off the road into a field, stopping suddenly. John got out and looked at the engine, pretending to know what he was doing. After a while, he admitted, "I actually have no idea what I'm doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was big, with just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was safer to be on her side. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. John went to find someone who knew about cars, and Mum lay on the grass. "Tell us a story," she said. Bea lay down next to her, and I told them about hearing two birds talking in London. They talked about breadcrumbs, other birds, and the weather. They even argued about a worm. Bea said, "That's silly, no one understands bird language." I insisted I did, but I wasn't sure anymore. Mum had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped push the van to a hotel. Bea didn't want to get out, but the boys smiled and waved at her. We went into a café near the road. "It's a hotel," John whispered. "It might be expensive." Mum said, "We'll just have some tea," and we sat in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum said, "It's like syrup." We stayed there all day while John tried to fix the van. "It's a miracle it got us this far," he said as it got dark. Mum made a bed for us outside in the hotel garden. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn't moving. John said, "I'll have to get us towed into Marrakech." Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed with John driving it. Bea didn't want to move, so John carried her to the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I wondered how we would get home since our van needed to be towed. I thought maybe we could take a boat to London. Then I fell asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom. She was talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. They were not competing like Lucy. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city. Lucy didn't hear the girl's name clearly because of the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. Both of them were about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well. They talked about the music they were playing and their travel plans. 
Lucy mentioned she might go to the Tanglewood festival in the summer. It sounded impressive, but she didn't really want to go. She often did things like concerts and competitions that took her around the world. Because of this, she missed a lot of school and wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. Lucy hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. Her mom had applied for her without telling her. Lucy's dad bought her a necklace to celebrate, and her little brother Gus dreamed of going to the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for dinner to plan her music pieces. Lucy thought her mom didn't want to give her the chance to say no to the festival.
The guy from Tokyo asked Lucy about Tanglewood. She told him she was fifteen. He and the girl, Liesel or Louisa, seemed impressed. Lucy didn't mean to show off. It was hard to know when she was just sharing information or bragging. Liesel or Louisa left to talk to someone else, but the guy from Tokyo stayed. He asked if Lucy had been to Japan. She said she went once when she was eight. 
Then, Lucy's grandfather came and took her away to introduce her to other people. He told her not to get too friendly with the competition. Lucy said they weren't the competition, but her grandfather thought everyone was. He made her talk to important people at the party. Lucy smiled and nodded, but she didn't hear everything they said. 
After the party, in the elevator, her grandfather told her she did well and that he was proud of her. He said the festival was important and that people were talking about her. Lucy liked being someone important, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young. Being a concert pianist didn't make her special at school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care about her music skills. But at the festival, Lucy felt like she mattered.

"It's not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world," said Dad. It's hard to argue with him, so I decided to see what experts say about it. It's quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of who they are, and are learning important technical skills for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is a big part of modern childhood. Teenagers don't just use media for things like buying tickets or checking emails like adults do; they live in it. It's not good or bad – it depends on how you use it.
How does our social networking compare to what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it's like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, which today's parents did when they were younger. It helps teenagers develop their identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and get along with friends.
Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says adolescence is a time when you ask, "Who am I?" Social networking can help you find your identity. You can share your favorite music or sports, discover what you like, and see that other people have different views. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don't use social media. He says social media can help if you're shy: communicating online can be easier than face-to-face, and it can help you practice social skills in a less scary way.
Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He thinks they can help if you're quiet and have a special interest because they let you connect with others who like the same things. If only a few people in your school like a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group with similar interests, you can feel popular in a different way.
Pauline White, a digital education expert, says teenagers who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded people, and create their own content are really using social networks well. She thinks social networking is becoming a creative force: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what interests them. Photo-sharing sites are changing creativity. Keen photographers can connect, learn skills, share images, and deepen their interest. This can help with jobs and will be useful in the workplace. Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness, so you need to understand how it works. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on social networks, they could be your customers. If you connect all those networks, there's your customer base.
Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and start working, agrees Matthews. One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create and share content. Collaboration is an important skill for the 21st century and helps you be employable in a digital age."

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they probably don't imagine a long trip through nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. But my parents wanted something different for our summer vacation this year. My dad planned what many teenagers would call a nightmare: a big family road trip. He and my mom kept saying, "Not enough people do this anymore," while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a good reason why!"
In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. We barely had room left in the car when we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." Leaving our big house for smaller places to stay over the next five thousand miles, I wondered what we were getting into.
We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under the darkest, starry skies, but only after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!
The next day, we were up early and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to feel the same, but each adventure was unique. We walked on the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly town gave us a hint of what was to come later in our trip. As we climbed to our next stop, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best for Jeep drivers. Everywhere we went, we saw a mix of old and new things. We got used to dealing with construction traffic. We laughed when we posed by the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.
We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common. Our own close encounter with a bear and a worried park ranger gave us unforgettable memories. As we traveled, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with no internet or cell phone service, didn't bother us. It was a 95-year-old building, but the views were amazing.
After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to a faraway place to find something special. It was both happy and sad to be home again, but at least I didn't fight with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our crazy journey to look through. I knew I would remember the unplanned and spontaneous moments the most.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, was going with him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy was finishing her last year of school and would live at the college under the care of the Head. She was happy because she got the best room with a kitchen and study area, and she could use the Internet and phone freely. Jeff and Dahlia would still check on Amy.
Rose was moving to her grandmother's house. She only remembered her grandmother from holidays and never knew her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, Rose's parents were not very excited, but Daisy insisted. Rose didn't know why her parents didn't get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Rose was ten years old the last time she saw her grandmother, but she had happy memories. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting because Daisy was very social and liked to bring people together. Rose expected to get dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon. This made Rose smile because her grandmother was very active and attended many social events.
Before moving, Dahlia and Rose talked. Rose was mature and knew about healthy living. She wanted independence, like playing music loudly, inviting friends over, or going out without asking for permission. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late. Daisy understood this. Rose's mother gave her a new phone with a video camera for emergencies. Rose was very happy. They agreed to trust each other. Daisy would trust Rose to make good decisions, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If there were problems, they would talk about it.
Rose was not a troublemaker. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. In five weeks, Rose would start a new school, make new friends, and start fresh. It was her fourth school in five years, so she was used to it. She knew this would be the last time because she was starting her final two years of school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger says her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a big achievement because it seemed difficult, and she didn't know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Amazingly, the novel she started then is about to be published. She recently told her old teacher, who was surprised. The teacher thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40. Charlotte didn't understand why she should wait if she had a chance to be good at it.
It's a winter afternoon at Charlotte's publisher's office. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was still surprised to see a teenager there. The book is a big achievement: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except the age of its main character, shows it was written by a teenager. A public relations person is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn't need any support. She is confident, smart, and steady, which stops her from being too confident.
Charlotte knows she is young. I ask her about the complex moral issues in her book. She says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don't have many life lessons to share," she laughs. "I don't think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I'm not particularly wise. I was just interested in exploring the theme of taking responsibility."
She has a theory about how teenagers are shown in books. She says there are three types of teenagers in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows nothing about the world, and the awkward teenager who isn't socially skilled. Reading about these types annoyed her. "What if you're basically fine? There aren't many stories about characters who aren't inadequate in some way. Some writers unintentionally make teenagers feel they can't know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-confidence."
Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy writers explore deep things about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I could do it." However, she praises a book called How Not to Write a Novel. "It says if the reader can guess what will happen, the suspense is probably gone."
Some might think Charlotte's parents, who are both journalists, helped her get her novel published. Her father's connection with someone in publishing got her book read initially. She knows she was lucky because getting a first novel read is hard, no matter the author's age. "Every writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you're on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don't take things for granted," Charlotte concludes.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then one guy, David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, wanted to show he knew what he was doing. He went first, skiing down the slope towards the jump. He went fast and flew into the air, but something was wrong. We held our breath. He hit the ground, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I liked practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it, and I was afraid of being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students jumped and tried new tricks, landing in foam cubes. It wasn’t a real introduction to what we’d face on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat part behind the jump before the slope goes down again. Land in the right zone, and you keep moving forward. Land on the flat, and you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body go fast towards the jump. My legs would almost stop as I got close, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body does in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, then found myself in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment I felt proud. But that didn’t last. On the last run of the day, I didn’t slow down as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed in the right zone. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you hold tightly to the safety bar. The ride stops for a moment, and you take a deep breath as the rollercoaster slowly climbs up. There is a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You move quickly forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Everything is a blur, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose to be there, just like millions of people who visit theme parks every year.
Amusement parks are a big business because people love the exciting rides. To create these thrilling experiences, many skilled people work behind the scenes. There are engineers, designers, and marketing experts who make sure the rides are fun and safe. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it is a real and challenging career. Designers must create rides that are both exciting and safe, and they need to come up with new ideas to keep visitors interested.
Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most of the techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rides were more extreme, but now designers have to work with the track designs made by specialist companies.
I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, an engineering expert, explained that the key is to make people feel like they are being thrown around but still safe. It's important to find the right balance between excitement and comfort.
To create a great ride, designers need to tell a story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and use new ideas like the tallest ride or the most twists. Professor Walker said that in the end, experience and trying different things are what work best. Jeff Hornick, a theme park development director, agreed that designers need to understand what passengers want and test the rides themselves.
I asked if new technology like virtual reality will change rollercoaster design. Walker said that while new technology can add to the experience, the physical rollercoaster will still be the main attraction for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer. She has created dances for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances sometimes. I wonder why she does both with her busy schedule. She says, ‘Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio and take orders from strict choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers can forget what it’s like to rehearse all day.’ As a choreographer, she teaches and likes working with young students. ‘New dancers are open to trying new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed but don’t fully know their strengths and weaknesses yet. This means they accept even tough criticism. They might still question me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback.’
When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. ‘There might be music I don’t like, but I still try to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a composer’s music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can’t just choose new music. I’d like to be more experimental and switch music when rehearsals are tough. But now, I work on big productions where the music is already decided by the composer and can’t be changed.’
Miranda doesn’t want to work with just one institution. ‘I think it’s important to meet new people. But I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. So, I have to change how I work each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing. This helps me not to become too set in my ways.’
We talk about a recent documentary on ballet dancers and choreographers. ‘Some documentaries look glamorous but are misleading,’ says Miranda. ‘This one tries to show what life is really like in a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer gets many corrections, and I recognized that. She knows she’s not doing it right but can’t make her body do it. It’s hard to watch but not fake. People don’t realize how much work and dedication ballet takes.’
I ask what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. ‘It’s when everything – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to ask, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences. It can help cover a few wrong artistic choices. I’ve been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props distracts. That’s disappointing.’
Miranda has done many different things, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? ‘People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s a trend to focus on one area, but I don’t follow that. Maybe one day I’ll be known for one thing, but for now, I want to explore more.’
